DT Article
TI Nineteen new species of Taperinha (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae:
   Deltocephalinae).
AU Freytag, Paul H. (freytag2104@windstream.net) 
SO Transactions of the American Entomological Society (Philadelphia)
VL 141
IS 3
PS 463-497
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 2
AB Nineteen new species are added to the Genus Taperinha Linnavouri from
   South America. The new species are Taperinha nuda, T. trigona, T.
   angulata, T. hamata, T. media, T. ungulata, T. lobata, T. anisota, T.
   lapayensis, T. odonta from Colombia; T. retusa, T. zanolae from French
   Guiana; T. dozieri, T. longicornis from Ecuador; T. elongata from
   Suriname; T. stypa from Venezuela; and T. bulba, T. stenostyla, T.
   peruviana from Peru. A key to the species known from Colombia is
   included.
C1 Freytag, Paul H.; Univ Kentucky, Dept Entomol, Lexington, KY, 40546,
   USA, USA.
EM freytag2104@windstream.net
SC Zoology
SN 0002-8320
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Documentation;
   Publications; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Revision of the Genus Eremidium Karsch with Descriptions of Sixteen New
   Species (Acridoidea: Lentulidae).
AU Otte, Daniel (otte@ansp.org) 
SO Transactions of the American Entomological Society (Philadelphia)
VL 141
IS 3
PS 499-544
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Twenty-seven species of Eremidium are now known. In this paper sixteen
   new species are named and described. The genus ranges along the eastern
   scarp of South Africa, preferring lush vegetation, often at the margins
   of forests, but also occurring in the eastern extension of the fynbos
   region of the Cape. Illustrations of Nyassacris are provided for
   comparison.
C1 Otte, Daniel; Acad Nat Sci, Dept Entomol, Philadelphia, PA, 19103, USA,
   USA.
EM otte@ansp.org
SC Zoology
SN 0002-8320
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Documentation; Publications; Land
   zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Eremidium [Checklists /  / Systematics] [South Africa /  /
   Distribution]. 
   Eremidium anono; Eremidium benga; Eremidium dosi; Eremidium gaape;
   Eremidium hunda; Eremidium kevusco; Eremidium macmac; Eremidium nodena;
   Eremidium oribi; Eremidium otuso; Eremidium pondo; Eremidium quati;
   Eremidium samada; Eremidium sesta; Eremidium sinka; Eremidium
   vernoncrookesi; Eremidium vuscu; Eremidium yandi [South Africa /  / New
   species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Orthoptera, Saltatoria

PT J
AN ZOOR15205030625
DT Article
TI In limbo no longer: a new genus for a rare Amazonian skipper, Telles
   pyrex Evans, 1955 (Hesperiidae: Hesperiinae).
AU Warren, Andrew D. (hesperioidea@yahoo.com) 
   Dolibaina, Diego R.
   Grishin, Nick V.
SO Tropical Lepidoptera Research
VL 25
IS 2
PS 46-51
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The male of the rare Amazonian skipper Telles pyrex Evans, 1955 is
   described and illustrated for the first time. This species has been
   without a generic affiliation, incertae sedis, since 2009. The generic
   placement of this species is investigated, considering characters from
   the male genitalia, wings, and DNA barcodes. Pseudorphe A. Warren &
   Dolibaina gen. nov. is proposed to accommodate this species, placed in
   the tribe Calpodini.
C1 Warren, Andrew D.; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist, 3215 Hull
   Rd,UF Cultural Plaza,POB 112710, Gainesville, FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM hesperioidea@yahoo.com
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Description;
   Combination
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae
OR Pseudorphe - A. Warren & Dolibaina 2015 (Hesperiidae): [Gen nov, Of
   tribe Calpodini, Type species Telles pyrex Evans 1955, p. 47]. 
   Pseudorphe pyrex - (Evans 1955) (Hesperiidae): [First time described,
   Male, p. 48; First time figured, Male, p. 48; Comb nov, Transferred from
   Telles, p. 49]. 
   Telles pyrex - Evans 1955 (Hesperiidae): [Designated type species for
   new genus, Pseudorphe, p. 47]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15205030625

DT Article
TI Three new species of Artines Godman, 1901 from Central and South America
   (Hesperiidae: Hesperiinae: Moncini).
AU Dolibaina, Diego R. (dirodrido@hotmail.com) 
   Warren, Andrew D.
   Carneiro, Eduardo
   Mielke, Olaf H.H.
SO Tropical Lepidoptera Research
VL 25
IS 2
PS 52-59
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Three new species of Artines Godman, 1901 are described: Artines Maya A.
   Warren & Dolibaina sp. nov. from Mexico, Belize and Guatemala; Artines
   steinhauseri Dolibaina & A. Warren sp. nov. from eastern Ecuador; and
   Artines mirnae O. Mielke, Dolibaina, Carneiro & A. Warren sp. nov. from
   Brazil (Piaui, Maranhao and Mato Grosso). Taxonomic comments, images of
   the adults and illustrations of the genitalia are provided for the new
   taxa. Additionally, in order to characterize these new species, taxa
   with similar wing patterns are illustrated and discussed, including A.
   rica Steinhauser & Austin, 1993, A. fosca Evans, 1995 and A. acroleuca
   (Plotz, 1884).
C1 Dolibaina, Diego R.; Univ Fed Parana, Dept Zool, POB 19020, Curitiba,
   Parana, BR-81531980 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM dirodrido@hotmail.com
RI Carneiro, Eduardo/C-6739-2013
OI Carneiro, Eduardo/0000-0002-4796-0020
SC Zoology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region;
   Neotropical region; North America; Central America; South America
DE Artines maya [Mexico /  / New species] [Belize /  / ] [Guatemala /  / ].
   
   Artines mirnae [Brazil /  / New species]. 
   Artines steinhauseri [Ecuador /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Hesperiidae

   Belize, P. 52].

   (Hesperiidae): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 57]. 
   Artines steinhauseri - Dolibaina & A. Warren 2015 (Hesperiidae): [Sp
   nov, Ecuador, P. 55].

TI Seven new species and one new subspecies of Euptychia Hubner, 1818
   (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Satyrinae) from the tropical Andes.
AU Nakahara, Shinichi (snakahara@ufl.edu) 
   Hall, Jason P.W.
   Lamas, Gerardo
   Willmott, Keith R.
SO Tropical Lepidoptera Research
VL 25
IS 2
PS 63-79
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Seven new species of Euptychia Hubner, 1818, E. truncata Nakahara &
   Hall, n. sp., E. pillaca Nakahara & Willmott, n. sp., E. padroni
   Nakahara, Lamas & Willmott, n. sp., E. enyita Nakahara, Lamas &
   Willmott, n. sp., E. granatina Nakahara, Le Crom & Hall, n. sp., E.
   fernandae Nakahara & Willmott, n. sp., E. pegasus Nakahara & Hall, n.
   sp., and one new subspecies E. cesarense obtusa Nakahara, n. ssp. are
   described herein. Adults and their genitalia are illustrated for all
   species and distribution maps are provided.

DT Article
TI On the taxonomy of the erythrina moths Agathodes and Terastia
   (Crambidae: Spilomelinae): Two different patterns of haplotype
   divergence and a new species of Terastia.
AU Sourakov, Andrei (asourakov@flmnh.ufl.edu) 
   Plotkin, David
   Kawahara, Akito Y.
   Xiao, Lei
   Hallwachs, Winnie
   Janzen, Daniel
SO Tropical Lepidoptera Research
VL 25
IS 2
PS 80-97
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Members of two species complexes in the family Crambidae feed on
   ornamental and medicinal plants of the genus Erythrina (Fabaceae),
   commonly known as coral beans and/or coral trees, in tropical and
   subtropical regions worldwide. Erythrina leaf-rollers (genus Agathodes)
   and erythrina borers (genus Terastia), although different ecologically
   and phenotypically, are sister genera. Each is represented by several
   very similar species. The erythrina leaf-rollers comprise a species
   complex that, in the New World, consists of Agathodes monstralis Guenee,
   1854 rev. stat. and A. designalis Guenee, 1854. We analyzed morphology
   and DNA barcoding data of populations throughout the geographic range
   and concluded that North American A. monstralis, which was previously
   demoted to the status of a subspecies of A. designalis, is a valid
   species. The two are sympatric in Costa Rica. In contrast, the erythrina
   borer, Terastia meticulosalis Guenee, 1854, which has a similar
   geographic distribution to A. designalis, shows no divergence in DNA
   barcodes and morphology in the New World. However, DNA barcode analyses
   and detailed morphological examinations of the Asian and African
   populations of Terastia meticulosalis species group show that these
   represent several species. Thus, a new species, Terastia africana
   Sourakov, sp. nov., is described and the status of T subjectalis
   Lederer, 1863 as a valid species is confirmed.
C1 Sourakov, Andrei; Univ Florida, Florida Museum Nat Hist, Gainesville,
   FL, 32611, USA, USA.
EM asourakov@flmnh.ufl.edu
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description; Taxonomy;
   Status; General morphology; Nutrition; Diet; Genetics; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Africa
DE Agathodes; Terastia [General morphology /  / systematics] [Food plants /
   Erythrina / ] [Molecular genetics / DNA barcoding / ] [Evolution /  / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
   Terastia africana [Malawi /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Pyraloidea, Pyralidae
OR Agathodes - Guenee (Pyralidae). 
   Agathodes designalis - Guenee 1854 (Pyralidae): [Redescription, P. 83]. 
   Agathodes designalis monstralis - Guenee 1854 (Pyralidae): [Raised to,
   Agathodes monstralis, p. 81]. 
   Agathodes monstralis - Guenee 1854 (Pyralidae): [Redescription, P. 81;
   Raised from, Agathodes designalis monstralis, p. 81]. 
   Terastia (Pyralidae). 
   Terastia africana - Sourakov 2015 (Pyralidae): [Sp nov, Malawi, P. 88]. 
   Terastia meticulosalis - Guenee 1854 (Pyralidae): [Redescription, P.
   85]. 
   Terastia subjectalis - Lederer 1863 (Pyralidae): [Emended diagnosis, P.
   88; Redescription, P. 87]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15205030629
DA 2020-09-17

TI A NEW SPECIES OF THE GENUS RAMULISETA (DIPTERA, CTENOSTYLIDAE) FROM

U1 0

DT Article
TI REVIEW OF THE GENUS GELOEMYIA (DIPTERA, PYRGOTIDAE), WITH DISCUSSION OF
   ITS TAXONOMIC POSITION.
AU Korneyev, V.A. (valery.korneyev@gmail.com) 
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 49
IS 6
PS 497-518
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Species assigned to Geloemyia Hendel, 1908, Trichempodia Malloch, 1930
   syn. n., Parageloemyia Hendel, 1933 syn. n., and Dicranostira Enderlein,
   1942 syn. n. are shown to be congeneric. Geloemyia is refined to include
   eight species: Geloemyia cheni Kim, Han & Korneyev, sp. n., Geloemyia
   cockerelli (Malloch, 1930) comb. n. (= Trichempodia cockerelli Malloch,
   1930), Geloemyia dorsocentralis (Hering, 1940) comb. n. (= Adapsilia
   dorsocentralis Hering, 1940), Geloemyia quadriseta Hendel, 1933,
   Geloemyia stylata Hendel, 1908, Geloemyia wonjuensis (Kim & Han, 2001)
   comb. n. (= Parageloemyia wonjuensis Kim & Han, 2001) from Eastern Asia,
   Geloemyia namibica sp. n., from mainland Africa (Namibia) and Geloemyia
   trifasciata (Enderlein, 1942) comb. n. (= Trichempodia trifasciata
   Enderlein, 1942) from Madagascar. Geloemyia nigrofasiata Hendel, 1933
   based on a single male is supposed to be a junior synonym of G.
   quadriseta Hendel, 1933, based on females, but the synonymy is
   tentative. A key to species is provided. The genus Geloemyia belongs in
   the tribe Pyrgotini forming (or belonging to) a basal lineage in the
   subtribe Adapsiliina together with Pyrgotomyia Hendel, 1914 and
   Porpomastix Enderlein, 1942.
C1 Korneyev, V.A.; NAS Ukraine, Schmalhausen Inst Zool, Vul B Khmelnytskogo
   15, Kyiv, UA-01030, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM valery.korneyev@gmail.com
RI Korneyev, Valery/O-1497-2016
OI Korneyev, Valery/0000-0001-9631-1038

SN 0084-5604

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Asia
DE Geloemyia cheni [South Korea /  / New species]. 
   Geloemyia namibica [Namibia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   Pyrgotidae

   Geloemyia, p. 507]. 
   Geloemyia - Hendel 1908 (Pyrgotidae): [Systematics, P. 497; Syn nov,

   p. 498; Syn nov, Trichempodia Malloch 1930, p. 498; Referred to,
   Adapsiliina, p. 500; Key to species, P. 500]. 
   Geloemyia cheni - Kim, Han & Korneyev 2015 (Pyrgotidae): [Sp nov, South
   Korea, P. 502]. 
   Geloemyia cockerelli - (Malloch 1930) (Pyrgotidae): [Redescription, P.

   Geloemyia dorsocentralis - (Hering 1940) (Pyrgotidae): [Redescription,
   P. 507; Comb nov, Transferred from Adapsilia, p. 507]. 
   Geloemyia namibica (Pyrgotidae): [Sp nov, Namibia, P. 508]. 
   Geloemyia nigrofasciata - Hendel 1933 (Pyrgotidae): [Status, P. 512]. 
   Geloemyia quadriseta - Hendel 1933 (Pyrgotidae): [Redescription, P.
   511]. 
   Geloemyia stylata - Hendel 1908 (Pyrgotidae): [Redescription, P. 513]. 
   Geloemyia trifasciata - (Enderlein 1942) (Pyrgotidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Trichempodia, p. 513]. 
   Geloemyia wonjuensis - (Kim & Han 2001) (Pyrgotidae): [Redescription, P.
   517; Comb nov, Transferred from Parageloemyia, p. 516]. 
   Parageloemyia wonjuensis - Kim & Han 2001 (Pyrgotidae): [Referred to,
   Geloemyia, p. 516]. 
   Trichempodia cockerelli - Malloch 1930 (Pyrgotidae): [Referred to,
   Geloemyia, p. 505]. 
   Trichempodia trifasciata - Enderlein 1942 (Pyrgotidae): [Referred to,
   Geloemyia, p. 513].

PT J
AN ZOOR15205029999
DT Article
TI ON THE SYNONYMY OF MICARIA MODESTA (ARANEI, GNAPHOSIDAE).
AU Mikhailov, K.G. (mikhailov2000@gmail.com) 
SO Vestnik Zoologii
VL 49
IS 6
PS 567-568
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB On the basis of examination of the type series of it is synonymized with
   Micaria rossica Thorell, 1875, Micaria modesta Kroneberg, 1875, a widely
   distributed and morphologically variable species.

DT Article
TI Fossils reveal a high diversity of the staghorn coral genera Acropora
   and Isopora (Scleractinia: Acroporidae) in the Neogene of Indonesia.
AU Santodomingo, Nadiezhda (nsantodomingo@gmail.com) 
   Wallace, Carden C.
   Johnson, Kenneth G.
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 175
IS 4
PS 677-763
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 12
AB Although Acropora is the most diverse and abundant coral genus on modern
   Indo-Pacific reefs, there is only limited understanding of its
   evolutionary history in the region. To help fill this gap, we consider
   the fossil record of Acropora and its sister clade Isopora, through
   examination of new extensive collections of well-preserved specimens
   from East Kalimantan, Indonesia, of Miocene age, historical museum
   collections, and literature records throughout the Indo-Pacific. We
   examined a total of 226 lots including 4720 specimens, from which 33
   species were described, 31 Acropora and two Isopora. Descriptions are
   based on qualitative morphological characters and 17 quantative
   characters. We report the first appearance in the fossil record of the
   nasuta, elegans and loripes species groups, in the Miocene. We describe
   seven new species: six Acropora (A. laurae, A. elenae, A. emanuelae, A.
   darrellae, A. hasibuani and A. renemai) and one Isopora (I. matahari)
   which, at 17.9 Ma, is the earliest known occurrence of Isopora.
   Moreover, we extend the occurrence of the species A. lavandulina and A.
   bartonensis, previously reported from the Eocene and Oligo-Miocene of
   Europe, into the Oligocene and Miocene of the Indo-Pacific,
   respectively. We confirm that 31 species within nine Acropora species
   groups were already present in the Indo-Pacific in the Miocene, with a
   maximum age of 18-20 Ma, supporting the large body of evidence
   indicating an early origin for most Acropora lineages and the
   evolutionary persistence of species groups throughout the Cenozoic.
   Based on our new data, 23 extant species have their earliest occurrence
   during the Neogene, including 12 that were already present in the Early
   Miocene. Four principal palaeoenvironments were interpreted from our
   samples of East Kalimantan, mostly associated with shallow turbid
   habitats. The arrangement sequence of radial corallites with respect to
   the axial corallite is proposed as a new morphological character to
   distinguish species and/or species groups. We expect that the full set
   of morphological features that we present in this study will allow the
   integration of the fossil record into comprehensive phylogenetic
   analyses that give more insights into the complex evolutionary history
   of Acropora. (C) 2015
C1 Santodomingo, Nadiezhda; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Earth Sci, Cromwell Rd,
   London, SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM nsantodomingo@gmail.com

DT Article
TI Integrative taxonomy of Parasabella and Sabellomma (Sabellidae:
   Annelida) from Australia: description of new species, indication of
   cryptic diversity, and translocation of some species out of their
   natural distribution range.
AU Capa, Maria (maria.capa@ntnu.no) 
   Murray, Anna
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 175
IS 4
PS 764-811
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Most nominal fan worm species belonging to the genus Parasabella Bush,
   1905, and Sabellomma Nogueira, Fitzhugh & Silva-Rossi, 2010 (Sabellidae,
   Annelida) lack unique morphological diagnostic features. Species
   diagnoses rely on a combination of attributes, often making reference to
   characters that are qualitatively or quantitatively continuous. This,
   together with a lack of knowledge about phenotypic intraspecific
   variation in most species, suggests that the sole use of morphological
   features is insufficient to identify and characterize some of these
   species. Examination of collections revealed that Parasabella is a
   common and diverse group of sabellids along the Australian coastline,
   although it had only been recorded here twice. The genus Sabellomma is
   here reported in Australia for the first time. Comparison of
   morphological data and nuclear (internal transcribed spacer) and
   mitochondrial (cytochrome oxidase I) DNA sequence data of 30 terminals
   in a range of analyses allowed us to assess the monophyly of Parasabella
   and its sister-group relationship with Sabellomma and to examine some of
   the species boundaries and genetic diversity within lineages. The
   combined sequence data results indicate the presence of seven distinct
   genetic Parasabella lineages in Australia, four of which are assigned to
   previously described species (three are new records for Australia), and
   two are considered as a complex of species sharing a unique combination
   of characters, one of which is described as new. Another Parasabella
   species with distinct atypical radiolar eyes and a species of Sabellomma
   are also described as new.
C1 Capa, Maria; NTNU Norwegian Univ Sci & Technol, Museum Nat Hist &
   Archaeol, Trondheim, N-7491, Norway, Norway.
EM maria.capa@ntnu.no

DT Article
TI Cladistic analysis and taxonomic revision of the genus Karos Goodnight &
   Goodnight, 1944 (Opiliones, Laniatores, Stygnopsidae).
AU Cruz-Lopez, Jesus A. (thelyphonidito@gmail.com) 
   Francke, Oscar F.
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 175
IS 4
PS 827-891
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A cladistic analysis of the genus Karos Goodnight & Goodnight, 1944, was
   performed using morphological data of the somatic and male genitalia
   characters. The analysis included 23 terminal taxa, including nine of
   the 11 described species of the genus plus nine new species according to
   the previous generic diagnosis and five species as outgroups. According
   to the topologies obtained by parsimony analyses, the genus is a
   paraphyletic assemblage, referred here as the Karos genus-group.
   Therefore, the genus Karos is rediagnosed here and now includes seven
   species: Karos barbarikos Goodnight & Goodnight, 1944 (type), Karos
   parvus Goodnight & Goodnight, 1971, Karos projectus Goodnight &
   Goodnight, 1971, Karos hexasetosus sp. nov., Karos monjarazi sp. nov.,
   Karos singularis sp. nov., and Karos tersum sp. nov. The genera
   Monterella Goodnight & Goodnight, 1944, Montabunus Goodnight &
   Goodnight, 1945, Chapulobunus Goodnight & Goodnight, 1946, and Potosa
   Goodnight & Goodnight, 1947 are revalidated, rediagnosed, their
   respective type species are redescribed and the following species are
   described: Chapulobunus poblano sp. nov. and Potosa reddelli sp. nov.
   The genera Crettaros gen. nov., Huasteca gen. nov., and Mictlana gen.
   nov., and the following species are described: Crettaros santibanezi sp.
   nov. (type), Crettaros valdezi sp. nov., and Huasteca silhavyi sp. nov.
   The following new combinations are proposed: Huasteca gratiosa
   (Goodnight & Goodnight, 1971) comb. nov. (type), Huasteca Rugosa
   (Goodnight & Goodnight, 1971) comb. nov. and Mictlana inops (Goodnight &
   Goodnight, 1971) comb. nov. (type). Karos brignolii Silhavy, 1974, is
   considered a junior synonym of Huasteca Rugosa. Finally, 'Karos'
   depressus Goodnight & Goodnight, 1971 is considered incertae sedis until
   adult males can be studied. Diagnoses of the Karos and Paramitraceras
   genus-groups, and an identification key to the eight genera and 19
   species of the former are provided. (C) 2015

   Postal 70-153, Mexico City, DF, 04510, Mexico, Mexico.

PM 26654039
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Preliminary Report of a Neurokinin-like Receptor Gene Sequence for the
   Nemertean Paranemertes sp.
AU Chung, Brian M. (brianchung@weber.edu) 
   Stevens, Rainee C.
   Thomas, Chelsie L.
   Palmere, Laura N.
   Okazaki, Robert K.
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 32
IS 6
PS 567-570
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Tachykinins (TKs) are a family of neurotransmitters that function as
   signaling molecules for such processes as maintaining homeostasis,
   regulating stress response, and modulating pain. TKs require the
   expression of at least one of three receptor subtypes: Neurokinin
   Receptor-1 (NKR-1), Neurokinin Receptor-2 (NKR-2), or Neurokinin
   Receptor-3 (NKR-3). We have isolated and cloned a portion of a gene
   coding for a tachykinin-like receptor from the nemertean Paranemertes
   sp. This 488-bp portion contains a short 101-bp segment that shares 85%
   similarity to the mouse substance-K receptor in Mus musculus and 83%
   similarity to the moth neuropeptide receptor A24 in Bombyx mori.
   Translated homology analysis aligning the coding sequence with the
   initial cytoplasmic carboxyl terminus of numerous G-protein coupled
   neuropeptide receptors also revealed 73% similarity to B. mori
   neuropeptide receptor A24. Our finding is the first report of a sequence
   amplified from Paranemertes sp. that may code for a small portion of a
   G-protein-coupled neuropeptide receptor with significant similarity to
   the TKR family, particularly the NKR-3 receptor isoform. This novel
   finding may open new avenues into exploring the role of tachykinin and
   its receptor in nemertean neurophysiology.
C1 Chung, Brian M.; Weber State Univ, Dept Zool, 1415 Edvalson St, Ogden,
   UT, 84408, USA, USA.
EM brianchung@weber.edu
SC Neurosciences &Neurology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0289-0003
BD Nervous system; Genetics
DE Paranemertes [Neurotransmitter receptors / Neurokinin-like receptor /
   first report] [Molecular genetics / Gene sequence / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Nemertinea
OR Paranemertes (Nemertinea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15205030103
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15205030107
PM 26654043
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Tubulanus tamias sp nov (Nemertea: Palaeonemertea) with Two Different
   Types of Epidermal Eyes.
AU Kajihara, Hiroshi (kazi@mail.sci.hokudai.ac.jp) 
   Kakui, Keiichi
   Yamasaki, Hiroshi
   Hiruta, Shimpei F.
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 32
IS 6
PS 596-604
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Based on specimens collected subtidally ([approximately]10 m in depth)
   in Tomioka Bay, Japan, we describe the palaeonemertean Tubulanus tamias
   sp. nov., which differs from all its congeners in body coloration. In
   molecular phylogenetic analyses based on partial sequences of the
   nuclear 18S and 28S rRNA genes and histone H3, as well as the
   mitochondrial 16S rRNA and cytochrome c oxidase subunit I genes, among
   selected palaeonemerteans, T. tamias nested with part of the congeners
   in Tubulanus, while the genus as currently diagnosed appears to be
   non-monophyletic. Molecular cloning detected polymorphism in 28S rDNA
   sequences in a single individual of T. tamias, indicating incomplete
   concerted evolution of multiple copies. Tubulanus tamias is peculiar
   among tubulanids in having 9-10 pigment-cup eyes in the epidermis on
   either side of the head anterior to the cerebral sensory organs, and
   remarkably there are two types of eyes. The anterior 8-9 pairs of eyes,
   becoming larger from anterior to posterior, are completely embedded in
   the epidermis and proximally abutting the basement membrane; each
   pigment cup contains bundle of up to seven, rod-shaped structure that
   resemble a rhabdomeric photoreceptor cell. In contrast, the
   posterior-most pair of eyes, larger than most of the anterior ones, have
   an optical cavity filled with long cilia and opening to the exterior,
   thus appearing to have ciliary-type photoreceptor cells. The size and
   arrangement of the eyes indicate that the posterior-most pair of eyes
   are the remnant of the larval (or juvenile) eyes.
C1 Kajihara, Hiroshi; Hokkaido Univ, Fac Sci, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 0600810,
   Japan, Japan.
EM kazi@mail.sci.hokudai.ac.jp
RI Kajihara, Hiroshi/N-4562-2019; Yamasaki, Hiroshi/I-8585-2018; Kakui,
   Keiichi/D-6108-2015
OI Kajihara, Hiroshi/0000-0001-6510-9355; Yamasaki,
   Hiroshi/0000-0002-0282-982X; Kakui, Keiichi/0000-0003-4630-9065
SC Zoology
SN 0289-0003
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Tubulanus tamias [North Pacific / Japan / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Nemertinea
OR Tubulanus tamias (Nemertinea): [Sp nov, Japan (marine), P. 598].

OA Green Published

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Arenogigas armoricus, a New Genus and Species of a Monostiliferous
   Hoplonemertean (Nemertea) from the North-West Coast of France.
AU Kraemer, Daria (dkraemer@evolution.uni-bonn.de) 
   von Doehren, Joern
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 32
IS 6
PS 605-614
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new genus and species of an endobenthic, unusually large
   eumonostiliferous hoplonemertean, Arenogigas armoricus gen. et sp. nov.,
   is described from an intertidal sandflat in Pouldohan Bay near
   Concarneau, France. Morphological characters of the species and genus
   include a prominent connective tissue that divides the anterior
   longitudinal musculature, an extremely branched vascular system, the
   absence of a pre-cerebral septum, a pair of eyes situated at the
   anterior tip of the head, small cerebral organs positioned far anterior
   to the brain, 10 proboscidial nerves, and nine accessory stylet pouches.
C1 Kraemer, Daria; Univ Bonn, Inst Evolutionary Biol & Ecol, Immenburg 1,
   Bonn, D-53121, Germany, Germany.
EM dkraemer@evolution.uni-bonn.de

   Ocean

DT Article; Meeting paper
TI Integrative Taxonomy of the Micrura alaskensis Coe, 1901 Species Complex
   (Nemertea: Heteronemertea), with Descriptions of a New Genus Maculaura
   gen. nov and Four New Species from the NE Pacific.
AU Hiebert, Terra Celeste (terrah@uoregon.edu) 
   Maslakova, Svetlana
SO Zoological Science (Tokyo)
VL 32
IS 6
PS 615-637
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Micrura alaskensis Coe, 1901 is a common intertidal heteronemertean
   known from eastern and northwest Pacific (Alaska to Ensenada, Mexico and
   Akkeshi, Japan, respectively). It is an emerging model system in
   developmental biology research. We present evidence from morphology of
   the adults, gametes, and sequences of cytochrome c oxidase subunit I and
   16S rRNA genes that it is not one, but a complex of five, cryptic
   species. All five of these species co-occur at least in part of their
   geographic range (e.g. southern Oregon). Preliminary cross-hybridization
   experiments suggest that at least some of these species are
   reproductively isolated. The five species share characteristics of adult
   morphology (e.g. accessory buccal glands) and at least four are known to
   possess a unique larval morphotype-pilidium maculosum. We propose that
   these characters define a new genus, Maculaura gen. nov., which contains
   the following five species: Maculaura alaskensis comb. nov., Maculaura
   aquilonia sp. nov., Maculaura cerebrosa sp. nov., Maculaura oregonensis
   sp. nov., and Maculaura magna sp. nov. It is unclear which of the five
   species Coe originally encountered and described. We chose to retain the
   name "alaskensis" for the species that current researchers know as
   "Micrura alaskensis", although, presently, it is only known from
   Washington and Oregon, and has not been collected from Alaska. Maculaura
   aquilonia sp. nov. is the only member of the genus we have encountered
   in Alaska, and we show that it also occurs in the Sea of Okhotsk,
   Russia.
C1 Hiebert, Terra Celeste; Univ Oregon, Oregon Inst Marine Biol,
   Charleston, OR, 97420, USA, USA.
EM terrah@uoregon.edu
SC Zoology
SN 0289-0003
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Type material;
   Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Maculaura aquilonia [North Pacific / Russia / New species] [ / USA,
   Alaska / ] [ / USA, Oregon / ]. 
   Maculaura cerebrosa [North Pacific / USA, California / New species] [ /
   USA, Oregon / ]. 
   Maculaura magna; Maculaura oregonensis [North Pacific / USA, Oregon /
   New species]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Nemertinea
OR Maculaura (Nemertinea): [Gen nov, Of family Lineidae, Type species
   Micrura alaskensis Coe 1901, p. 620]. 
   Maculaura alaskensis - (Coe 1901) (Nemertinea): [Redescription, P. 622;
   Comb nov, Transferred from Micrura, p. 621]. 
   Maculaura aquilonia (Nemertinea): [Sp nov, USA, Alaska (marine), P.

   628]. 
   Maculaura magna (Nemertinea): [Sp nov, USA, Oregon (marine), P. 629].

   630]. 
   Micrura alaskensis - Coe 1901 (Nemertinea): [Designated type species for

   Micrura griffini - Coe 1905 (Nemertinea): [Status, P. 634].

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022769
DT Article
TI Bats (Chiroptera) from Olduvai Gorge, Early Pleistocene, Bed I
   (Tanzania).
AU Gunnell, Gregg F.
   Butler, Percy M.
   Greenwood, Marjorie
   Simmons, Nancy B.
SO American Museum Novitates
VL 3846
PS 1-35
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania is most famous for producing some of the first
   discoveries of fossil hominins in East Africa. Zinjanthropus (=
   Paranthropus) boisei was initially discovered in 1959 from Olduvai Bed
   I. During screen-washing operations to search for more hominin material
   at Olduvai, an associated faunal assemblage was accumulated including 40
   numbered specimens of fossil bats. Except for seven dental specimens,
   this collection consists entirely of postcrania, almost exclusively
   complete or fragmentary humeri representing both proximal and distal
   ends. Although briefly discussed in preliminary reports, these specimens
   have remained undescribed for over 50 years and have never been
   comprehensively compared to extant species. Our analyses indicate that
   the Olduvai bat fossils represent five families and nine genera, and
   include four new species: Myzopoda africana, n. sp., Cardioderma
   leakeyi, n. sp., Scotoecus olduvensis, n. sp., and Nycticeinops
   serengetiensis, n. sp. The Olduvai bat fossils come from the FLK North 1
   and FLK NN1 levels, both of early Pleistocene age, and ranging between
   1.80 and 1.85 Ma based on 40Ar/39Ar dating techniques, respectively.
   Compared to the meager Pleistocene bat record from elsewhere on mainland
   Africa, the Olduvai bat assemblage, although richer, is similar in the
   predominance of vespertilionids. The East African Olduvai bat fauna
   differs from Pleistocene faunas from South Africa in including both
   Myzopoda and Cardioderma but lacking both hipposiderids and
   rhinolophids. These taxonomic differences are likely the result of
   differential sampling due to variation in roosting site preferences
   (cave-dwelling vs. non-cave-dwelling taxa) and foraging habitats (open
   vs. forested) in East and South Africa.
C1 Gunnell, Gregg F.; Duke Lemur Ctr, Div Fossil Primates, Durham, NC,
   27705, USA, USA.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0003-0082; 1937-352X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary
DE Cardioderma leakeyi; Myzopoda africana; Nycticeinops serengetiensis;
   Scotoecus olduvensis [Tanzania /  / new species] [Pleistocene /  / ]. 
   Chiroptera [Fossil assemblages /  / Systematics] [Tanzania / Olduvai
   Gorge / ] [Pleistocene / Early Pleistocene / ]. 
TN Bats; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Chiroptera, Megadermatidae,
   Myzopodidae, Vespertilionidae
OR Chiroptera (Mammalia): [Fossil]. 
   Cardioderma leakeyi (Megadermatidae): [Sp nov, Tanzania, Pleistocene, P.
   7; Fossil]. 
   Myzopoda africana (Myzopodidae): [Sp nov, Tanzania, Pleistocene, P. 3;
   Fossil]. 
   Nycticeinops serengetiensis (Vespertilionidae): [Sp nov, Tanzania,
   Pleistocene, P. 17; Fossil]. 
   Scotoecus olduvensis (Vespertilionidae): [Sp nov, Tanzania, Pleistocene,
   P. 10; Fossil].

PT J

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of lohmanniid oribatid mites (Acari:
   Oribatida: Lohmanniidae) of Cuba.
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Tolstikov, Andrei V.
SO Biologia (Bratislava)
VL 70
IS 12
PS 1614-1620
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A list of identified oribatid mites of the family Lohmanniidae (Acari,
   Oribatida) collected from Cuba, including 4 species from 4 genera, is
   provided. The genus Heptacarus and species Heptacarus supertrichus
   Piffl, 1967 are recorded in Cuba for the first time. A new species of
   Annectacarus is described from leaf litter in forest of Valle de Vinales
   National Park. Annectacarus vinalesensis sp. n. is morphologically most
   similar to A. krachan Mahunka, 1995, but the new species differs from
   the latter by the rostrum with indentation and the presence of six pairs
   of neotrichal notogastral setae and six pairs of setae on epimere I. An
   identification key to the known species of Annectacarus in the
   Neotropical region is given.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
RI Tolstikov, Andrey/B-2119-2013
OI Tolstikov, Andrey/0000-0002-8537-038X
SC Zoology
SN 0006-3088
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies
DE Annectacarus [Neotropical region /  / Key to species]. 
   Annectacarus vinalesensis [Cuba /  / New species]. 
   Heptacarus; Heptacarus supertrichus [Cuba /  / New record]. 
   Lohmanniidae [Cuba /  / Distribution; faunal list; systematics]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Annectacarus - Grandjean 1950 (Acari): [Key to species, Neotropical
   region, P. 1619]. 
   Annectacarus vinalesensis (Acari): [Sp nov, Cuba, P. 1614]. 
   Heptacarus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Heptacarus supertrichus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Lohmanniidae (Acari).

TI New or interesting Cerambycidae from the Philippines (Part XIII),
   Revision del genero Pseudabryna Schultze,1916 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae,
   Lamiinae).
AU Vives, Eduard (eduard_vives@hotmail.com) 
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 20
PS 1-7
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 1
AB The species in the genus Pseudabryna Schultze are revised, together with
   a redescription of the genus and its four species. Taxonomic keys to
   distinguish these species are provided. Two new combinations are
   proposed for P. aurorana Vives, comb. nov. and P. hieroglyphica
   (Schultze) comb. nov.; the male genitalia of both species is studied,
   including for the first time the morphology of the endophallus.

TI [Description of 50 new Asian Long-Horned Beetles (Coleoptera,

   Cerambycidae).
AU Holzschuh, Carolus

PS 14-75

U2 0
AB Description of 50 new Longhorn Beetles from Asia (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae). Described and illustrated are: 3 from Sumatra: Ceresium
   aemulator sp. nov., C. grandicolle sp. nov., and Erythrus rectisuturalis
   sp. nov.; 1 from Bali: Erythrus marginiger sp. nov.; 17 from Borneo,
   East Malaysia: Ceresium hirtipes sp. nov., C. subflavum sp. nov., C.
   callosum sp. nov., C. suturatum sp. nov., C. triguttatum sp. nov., C.
   opacu/um sp. nov., C. contiguum sp. nov., C. finitimum sp. nov., C.
   vicinum sp. nov., Examnes pubens sp. nov., Tethionea imitata sp. nov.,
   Merionoeda adjecta sp. nov., M. notabilis sp. nov., Molorchoepania
   brevitarsis sp. nov., Kurarua pennata sp. nov., Prothema decoratum sp.
   nov., and Erythrus brevidentatus sp. nov.; 7 from West Malaysia:
   Ceresium falsum sp. nov., C. aeneonigrum sp. nov., Merionoeda
   pubiventris sp. nov., M. aequalis sp. nov., Glaphyra externa sp. nov.,
   Prothema auratum recticulatum ssp. nov., and Erythrus nigrospadix sp.
   nov.; 10 from China: Stenhomalus pinicola sp. nov., Kunbir atripes
   bicoloripes ssp. nov., Epania ignota sp. nov., Glaphyra rugata sp. nov.,
   Glaphyra terminata sp. nov., Glaphyra macella sp. nov., Dere nigripennis
   sp. nov., Monochamus rectus sp. nov., M abruptus sp. nov., and M
   foraminosus sp. nov.; 4 from Laos: Chinobrium plaiythorax sp. nov.,
   Merionoeda atri color sp. nov., Glaphyra imprimis sp. nov., and G.
   propinqua sp. nov.; 5 from Thailand: Ceresium notaticolle sp. nov.,
   Kurarua obfuscata sp. nov., Dere minima sp. nov., Erythrus nayani
   decipiens ssp. nov., and Erythrus crassimargo sp. nov.; 1 from Nepal:
   Prothema auratum brunnipenne ssp. nov.; 1 from Sri Lanka: Plutonesthes
   advena sp. nov. und 1 from Oman: Iranobrium grande sp. nov.; Examnes
   elongatithorax Hayashi, 1979 is transferred to Ceresium Newman, 1842.
   Variations of Erythrus serratus Holzschuh, 2009 from Borneo are
   illustrated.

DT Article
TI [Description of a new species of Prosopocera from Cameroon (Coleoptera
   Cerambycidae).]
FT Description d'une nouvelle espece de Prosopocera du Cameroun (Coleoptera
   Cerambycidae).
AU Vitali, Carlo
   Vitali, Francesco
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 20
PS 82-85
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB Prosopocera (Alphitopola) oremansi n. sp. from Cameroon is described. It
   is characterized by a peculiar pattern that superficially reminds
   Prosopocera (s. str.) lactator (Fabricius, 1801) but is closer to
   Prosopocera (Alphitopola) gahani (Aurivillius, 1925), from which it
   differs in the larger size and the uniformly greenish-white pronotum and
   elytral disc.
C1 Vitali, Carlo; Via S Giorgio 5, Postalesio, Sondrio, I-23010, Italy,
   Italy.

DT Article
TI Addition to the knowledge of the genus Dinoprionus Bates, 1875 with the
   descriptions of a new species from Asia and of the female of D.
   cephalotes Bates, 1875 (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae, Prioninae).
AU Drumont, Alain (alain.drumont@naturalsciences.be) 
   Cuong Do
SO Cahiers Magellanes-NS
VL 20
PS 92-103
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Dinoprionus Bates, 1875 is described from
   Vietnam, under the name D. cooperi n. sp. It is also distributed in Laos
   and Myanmar. The new species is illustrated and compared with
   Dinoprionus cephalotes Bates, 1875 which was up to now the only species
   included in this genus. The female of D. cephalotes is described for the
   first time and discussed.

   tricuspidalis n. sp., Y ligulatus n. sp., Y duplodentatus n. sp., Y

   chlamysardetis n. sp., Y gladius n. sp., Y annularis n. sp. and Y

   sp., and Y schereri n. sp. to species group 2.

DT Article
TI Notes on the biology, distribution and taxonomy of Chondrostega LEDERER,
   1857 in the Iberian Peninsula with a description of the southern Spanish
   Chondrostega escobesae sp nov (Lepidoptera: Lasiocampidae,
   Chondrosteginae).
AU de Freina, Josef J. (defreina.j@online.de) 
   Monasterio Leon, Yeray
   Alberto Antonietty, Carlos
   Vila, Roger
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 125
IS 4
PS 195-207
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Spanish populations of Chondrostega LEDERER, 1857 are examined based on
   external and internal morphology as well as molecular data from the
   mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase subunit I gene (COI). According to
   relevant diagnostic features and genetic differentiation, two species
   with allopatric distribution are recognized within the Iberian
   Peninsula. Andalusian populations, here described as Chondrostega
   escobesae sp. nov., are compared to the closely related Chondrostega
   vandalicia (MILLIERE, 1865), which is limited to the northern half of
   the Iberian Peninsula. They can be recognized by largely constant
   morphological features such as a different pattern on the underside of
   the wings of the male, adult male genital structure, different structure
   of the canthus and the colour of hairs in the final instars.
   Phylogenetic analyses based on COI identify the two species as sister
   clades with a minimum genetic divergence of 3.8%. Adults, including the
   apterous females, immature stages, larval host plants and natural
   habitat are described and illustrated. A neotype is designated for C.
   vandalicia.
C1 de Freina, Josef J.; Eduard Schmid Str 10, Munich, D-81541, Germany,
   Germany.
EM defreina.j@online.de
RI Vila, Roger/A-1817-2012
OI Vila, Roger/0000-0002-2447-4388
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8843
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Chondrostega escobesae [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Bombycoidea, Lasiocampidae
OR Bombyx vandalicia - Milliere 1865 (Lasiocampidae): [Neotype designated,
   P. 198]. 
   Chondrostega escobesae (Lasiocampidae): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 200]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15204026490
DA 2020-09-17

TI Praemerothrips hoodi PRIESNER, 1929 and Merothrips balticus sp nov - Two
   new fossils of Thrips from Baltic Tertiary amber (Thysanoptera:
   Merothripidae).
AU Ulitzka, Manfred R. (manfred.ulitzka@thysanoptera.de) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 125
IS 4
PS 213-216
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present study deals with two fossil thrips species of Merothripidae.
   Both are preserved as inclusions in Baltic Tertiary Amber (Eocene). Only
   one of these fossils represents a genuinely new species, the other one
   is described as Praemerothrips hoodi PRIESNER, 1929. Due to the loss of
   its holotype specimen during the Second World War, a neotype is
   designated.

DT Article
TI Erebia claudina flammarum subsp nov., a remarkable new record for Italy
   (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae, Satyrinae).
FT Erebia claudina flammarum subsp. nov., ein bemerkenswerter Neufund fur
   Italien (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae, Satyrinae).
AU Nardelli, Uberto (unfebo@hotmail.it) 
   Huemer, Peter
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 125
IS 4
PS 217-222
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB During the summer 2005, the first author discovered a small relict
   population of Erebia claudina (BORKHAUSEN, 1789) in Italy (Trentino,
   Fiemme valley) at an elevation of ca. 1800m. The record is of
   exceptional interest due to the distribution pattern of this Erebia
   species restricted to the eastern-central Alps of Austria and thus
   considered as the only butterfly endemic to Austria. The considerable
   distance between the Austrian and the Italian localities, separated by
   noteworthy natural barriers, support the suspected interruption of gene
   flow between populations in both localities. Short sequences (407 bp) of
   the COI gene agree with a complete DNA barcode of nominotypical E.
   claudina and give evidence for a close relationship. However, based on
   the isolation of the Italian population, as well as morphological
   differences in the male sex a new subspecies, Erebia claudina flammarum
   subsp. nov., is described. Habitat, adults and male genitalia are
   described and figured in colour.
C1 Nardelli, Uberto; Via Ss Cosma & Damiano 9-2, Trento, Vela, I-38121,
   Italy, Italy.
EM unfebo@hotmail.it
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 0013-8843
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Genetics;
   Population genetics; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe
DE Erebia claudina [General morphology /  / systematics] [Gene flow /  / ]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Austria / Eastern central Alps / biology;
   distribution] [Italy /  / ]. 
   Erebia claudina flammarum [Italy /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Papilionoidea, Nymphalidae
OR Erebia claudina - (Borkhausen 1789) (Nymphalidae). 
   Erebia claudina flammarum (Nymphalidae): [Subsp nov, Italy, P. 219].

TI Distributional notes on Nosodendridae (Coleoptera) - XIV. Descriptions
   of three new species and new faunistics records from Philippines.
AU Hava, Jiri (jh.dermestidae@volny.cz) 
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 125
IS 4
PS 223-224
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three new species, Nosodendron parahispidum sp. nov., Nosodendron planus
   sp. nov. and Nosodendron bolmi sp. nov. all from Philippines are
   described, illustrated and compared with related species. New species
   differs by the structure of antennae, male genitalia and striation on
   abdominal ventrites. Nosodendron nomurai HAVA, 2000 is newly recorded
   for Philippines.

DT Article
TI Bicolorizea gen. nov. from tropical Africa (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae,
   Galerucinae).
AU Heunemann, Lars Oliver (thwagner@uni-koblenz.de) 
   Dalstein, Vivian
   Schulze, Melanie
   Wagner, Thomas
SO Entomologische Zeitschrift
VL 125
IS 4
PS 235-246
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Four species of Afrotropical Galerucinae, Monolepta basalis HAROLD, 1880
   (including its junior synonym Monolepta vulgaris ALLARD, 1888), M.
   cavidorsis FAIRMAIRE, 1893, M. pectoralis JACOBY, 1899, and Pseudocrania
   semi-fulva BRYANT, 1956 are revised and transferred to: Bicolorizea gen.
   nov. These taxa share the peculiar pattern of bicoloured elytra, where a
   black base is contrasting to the apical part next to characteristic male
   genital pattern. They are most closely related to Afrocrania HINCKS,
   1949 and Afrocandezea WAGNER & SCHERZ, 2002. Redescriptions are given
   four all species including drawings on external and genital morphology,
   photographs of all primary types, distribution maps and an
   idnetifikation key.
C1 Heunemann, Lars Oliver; Univ Koblenz Landau, Inst Integrierte Nat
   Wissensch Biol, Univ Str 1, Koblenz, D-56070, Germany, Germany.
EM thwagner@uni-koblenz.de

SN 0013-8843

   Description; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Afrotropical region

   P. 243; Comb nov, Transferred from Monolepta, p. 241].

PT J
AN ZOOR15204026427
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI New crayfish species records from the Sipsey Fork drainage, including
   Lewis Smith Reservoir (Alabama, USA): Native or introduced species?
AU Adams, Susan B. (sadams01@fs.fed.us) 
   Roghair, Craig
   Krause, Colin
   Warren, Melvin L., Jr
   Cochran, J. Allison
   Dolloff, Andy
   Moran, John
   McGregor, Stuart W.
   Schuster, Guenter A.
   Gangloff, Michael
   DeVries, Dennis R.
   Kendrick, Michael R.
   Grove, G. Lee
   Wright, Russell A.
SO Freshwater Crayfish
VL 21
IS 1
PS 17-32
PD December 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As part of a study of aquatic faunal community changes along
   riverine-lacustrine transition zones upstream of Lewis Smith Reservoir
   in northwest Alabama, USA, we collected crayfish from 60 sites in the
   Sipsey Fork, Brushy Creek, and selected tributaries (Black Warrior River
   system). After finding two unexpected and possibly-introduced crayfish
   species, we expanded our investigation of crayfish distributions to
   include crayfish obtained from stomachs of black bass (Micropterus spp.)
   caught at seven sites in the reservoir. To explore what crayfish species
   were in the drainage historically, we examined museum databases as well
   as stomach and intestinal contents of a variety of preserved fishes that
   were caught in the Sipsey Fork and Brushy Creek drainages upstream of
   the reservoir in the early 1990's. Of the seven crayfish species
   collected, one, Orconectes (Procericambarus) sp. nr ronaldi, was not
   previously reported from Alabama, and another, O. lancifer, was not
   reported from the Black Warrior River system prior to the study. Three
   are known or possibly introduced species. Upstream of the reservoir, the
   native species Cambarus obstipus, C. striatus, and O. validus were
   common. The same three species were found in fish collected in the
   1990's. Orconectes perfectus was found only in the reservoir but may be
   native to the drainage. Orconectes lancifer was in the reservoir and in
   stream reaches influenced by the reservoir. Evidence points to O.
   lancifer being introduced in the drainage, but this is uncertain.
   Orconectes sp. nr ronaldi was found in a relatively small portion of
   Brushy Creek and its tributaries, in both flowing and impounded
   habitats, and may be introduced. Orconectes virilis is introduced in
   Alabama and was found only in stomachs of fish collected in the
   reservoir.
C1 Adams, Susan B.; USDA Forest Service, Southern Research Station, Center
   for Bottomland Hardwoods Research, Oxford, Mississippi 38655, USA, USA.
EM sadams01@fs.fed.us
OI Kendrick, Michael/0000-0002-6137-0326
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology;
   Nutrition &Dietetics
SN 2076-4324; 2076-4332
BD Nutrition; Diet; Prey; Ecology; Predators; Habitat; Freshwater habitat;
   Lentic water; Lotic water; Zoogeography; Dispersal; Means of dispersal;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; USA
DE Astacura [Piscean predators /  / Predator prey relationships; new
   record; native & introduced species] [Distribution within habitat /  / ]
   [Reservoir /  / ] [Stream /  / ] [Zoogeography / Zoogeographical origins
   / ] [Introduction / Introduction pathways / ] [Alabama / Sipsey Fork
   Drainage & Lewis Smith Reservoir / ]. 
   Orconectes (Procericambarus) cf. ronaldi [Alabama /  / New record]. 
   Orconectes lancifer [Alabama / Black Warrior River system / New record].
   
   Pisces [Crustacean prey / Astacura / Predator prey relationships; prey
   zoogeography] [Reservoir /  / ] [Stream /  / ] [Alabama / Sipsey Fork
   Drainage & Lewis Smith Reservoir / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Chordates; Crustaceans; Fish; Invertebrates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca, Eucarida,
   Decapoda, Reptantia, Astacura, Chordata, Vertebrata
OR Astacura (Reptantia): [Prey; New record]. 
   Orconectes (Procericambarus) cf. ronaldi (Astacura): [New record]. 
   Orconectes lancifer (Astacura): [New record]. 
   Pisces (Vertebrata): [Predator]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15204026427
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15204022808
DT Article
TI A new Devonian asteroid-like ophiuroid from Spain.
AU Blake, D.B.
   Zamora, S. (dblake@illinois.edu) 
   Garcia-Alcalde, J.L.
SO Geologica Acta
VL 13
IS 4
PS 335-343
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB A Lochkovian (Early Devonian) ophiuroid (Echinodennata), Ophiocantabria
   elegans n. gen. and sp., is based on a single small, well-preserved
   specimen collected from a shale-rich horizon of the Furada Formation,
   Asturias, Spain. Sedimentologic and palaeontologic data suggest its
   occurrence was in a near-shore setting subjected to frequent storms.
   Ophiocantabria is assigned to the Encrinasteridae based on the
   morphology of individual skeletal elements, although overall form of the
   new species is similar to that of approximately coeval members of the
   asteroid family Xenasteridae. Such homoplasy, especially among earlier
   members of asterozoan class-level clades, is an important but not well
   understood aspect of subphylum evolution.
C1 Zamora, S.; Inst Geol & Minero Espana, C Manuel Lasala 44,9 B, Zaragoza,
   50006, Spain, Spain.
EM dblake@illinois.edu
SC Zoology
SN 1695-6133

PT J

DT Article
TI Famennian rhynchonellides (Brachiopoda) from deep-water facies of the
   Ougarta Basin (Saoura Valley, Algeria).
AU Mottequin, Bernard (bmottequin@naturalsciences.be) 
   Malti, Fatima Zohra
   Benyoucef, Madani
   Cronier, Catherine
   Samar, Louisa
   Randon, Carine
   Brice, Denise
SO Geological Magazine
VL 152
IS 6
PS 1009-1024
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB In the Saoura Valley (Ougarta Basin, Saharan Algeria), the lower-upper
   Famennian part of the essentially shally Marhouma Formation is
   characterized by deep-water facies and includes horizons rich in
   ammonoids (goniatites and clymeniids) and blind to eye-reduced phacopide
   trilobites. They are also rich in small-sized and smooth rhynchonellide
   brachiopods, investigated here for the first time in order to detail
   their post-Kellwasser recovery. Rhynchonellides clearly predominate in
   the brachiopod assemblages (representing 90% of the whole assemblage,
   with 10 species) composed otherwise of athyridides, orthides and
   spiriferides. Rhynchonellides are mostly represented by relatively flat
   leiorhynchids and rozmanariids consistent with poor oxygenation on the
   sea floor. One new species is described (Evanidisinurostrum saouraense
   sp. nov.); four genera, previously known only from the south-eastern
   margin of Laurussia, are reported for the first time from the northern
   margin of Gondwana: the leiorhynchid Sphaeridiorhynchus and the
   rozmanariids Leptoterorhynchus, Pugnaria and Novaplatirostrum.

PT J
AN ZOOR15204023435
DT Article
TI Asteroid (Echinodermata) skeletal elements from upper Oligocene deposits
   of Jamaica and Antigua.
AU Blake, Daniel B.
   Donovan, Stephen K. (Steve.Donovan@naturalis.nl) 
   Mah, Christopher L.
   Dixon, Harold L.
SO Geological Magazine
VL 152
IS 6
PS 1043-1056
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Antillean Cenozoic fossil record of asteroids comprises mainly
   dissociated ossicles. Most common among isolates from upper Oligocene
   deposits of Jamaica and Antigua are marginal ossicles of an extinct,
   indeterminate species of Pycinaster. This is the youngest known
   occurrence of the genus and the first from beyond Europe. A number of
   relatively complete fossils have been assigned to Pycinaster and (sub)
   familial status proposed for it together with Phocidaster. The latter
   proposition is based solely on a few marginals, but available diagnoses
   are judged insufficient to justify such recognition. The taxon
   Pycinasteridae is here synonymized with the Goniasteridae, although
   future study of added features (such as the ventral surface) might
   justify recognition at a higher taxonomic level. In addition to ossicles
   assigned to Pycinaster, many marginals are tentatively assigned to the
   surviving goniasterid Nymphaster. Numerous generic and many species
   names have been based on asteroid isolates, but the practice demands
   assumptions that are not readily justified. Linkage of discrete isolates
   under a single taxon name assumes derivation from a single source, an
   inference that can be verified only rarely (if ever), therefore reducing
   names to the single holotype ossicle. Availability of only isolates
   encourages comparison with extant taxa and biogeography, biasing
   interpretations with a Holocene overlay. Because of these constraints, a
   new nominal species of Pycinaster is not justified and assignment of
   ossicles to Nymphaster is tentative. However, given the importance of
   asteroids in marine communities, we emphasize the significance, largely
   ignored, of their presence in Cenozoic deposits of the wider Caribbean.
C1 Donovan, Stephen K.; Naturalis Biodivers Ctr, Dept Geol, Darwinweg 2,
   Leiden, NL-2333 CR, Netherlands, Netherlands.
EM Steve.Donovan@naturalis.nl
RI Donovan, Stephen K/O-1285-2015
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0016-7568
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Land zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies; Geological
   time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Nymphaster [Skeletal ossicles /  / Systematics] [Antigua and Barbuda /
   Antigua / ] [Jamaica /  / ] [Oligocene / Upper Oligocene / ]. 
   Pycinaster [Skeletal ossicles /  / Systematics] [Antigua and Barbuda /
   Antigua / ] [ /  / youngest record] [Jamaica /  / ] [ /  / ] [Oligocene
   / Upper Oligocene / ] [ /  / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15204023436
DT Article
TI The middle lower Cambrian (Ovetian) Lunagraulos n. gen. from Spain and
   the oldest trilobite records.
AU Linan, Eladio
   Gamez Vintaned, Jose Antonio
   Gozalo, Rodolfo (Rodolfo.Gozalo@uv.es) 
SO Geological Magazine
VL 152
IS 6
PS 1123-1136
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 6
AB The type material of Agraulos antiquus Sdzuy, 1961 from the La Herreria
   Formation, northern Spain, is revised together with additional material
   and included in the new genus Lunagraulos. The stratigraphical range of
   Lunagraulos antiquus (Sdzuy, 1961) - occurring below that of the
   trilobite species of the genera Lunolenus, Metadoxides and Dolerolenus
   in the type locality of Los Barrios de Luna in the province of Leon,
   northern Spain - and the accompanying ichnofossil assemblage demonstrate
   an Ovetian age (lower part of Cambrian Stage 3, currently being
   discussed by the International Subcommission on Cambrian Stratigraphy)
   for this species. Moreover, the trilobite Lunagraulos tamamensis n. gen.
   n. sp. is found in the Tamames Sandstone near the village of La
   Rinconada in the province of Salamanca, central Spain. The
   biostratigraphical position of this new taxon and its accompanying
   ichnoassemblage is also analysed and assigned to the lowermost Ovetian
   Stage. The genus Lunagraulos is therefore the oldest agraulid found in
   the fossil record. The exceptional presence of Lunagraulos in a marine
   coarse siliciclastic succession - a facies rather typical for the
   ichnofossils Cruziana and Rusophycus, some of the oldest signs of
   trilobite activity - suggests that first trilobite representatives may
   have inhabited high-to middle-energy, marine environments. This
   hypothesis may also explain both the taxonomic and biostratigraphic
   heterogeneity of the first trilobite genera appearing across the world,
   due to preservation problems in this type of facies. Comparison of the
   Lunagraulos biostratigraphy with other coeval Spanish fossil assemblages
   allows us to propose its intercontinental correlation with the oldest
   records of currently known trilobites.
C1 Gozalo, Rodolfo; Univ Valencia, Dept Geol, Dr Moliner 50, Burjassot,
   E-46100, Spain, Spain.
EM Rodolfo.Gozalo@uv.es
RI Gozalo, Rodolfo/I-1962-2012; Gamez Vintaned, Jose Antonio/K-7683-2014
OI Gozalo, Rodolfo/0000-0001-7985-9843; Gamez Vintaned, Jose
   Antonio/0000-0002-6604-4415
SC Zoology
SN 0016-7568
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods;
   Palaeozoic
DE Agraulidae [Spain /  / oldest record] [Cambrian / Lower Cambrian / ]. 
   Lunagraulos [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Lunagraulos tamamensis [Spain /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Invertebrates; Trilobites

OR Agraulidae (Trilobita): [Fossil].

   new genus, Lunagraulos, p. 1125]. 
   Lunagraulos (Trilobita): [Gen nov, Of family Agraulidae, Type species
   Agraulos antiquus Sdzuy 1961, p. 1125, Cambrian; Fossil].

   from Agraulos, p. 1127].

   Fossil].

DT Article
TI A Summary and Discussion of Helminth Parasites Reported from Xantusiid
   Lizards with a New Nematode Record from Lepidophyma smithii (Squamata:
   Xantusiidae).
AU Goldberg, Stephen R. (sgoldberg@whittier.edu) 
   Bursey, Charles R.
   Bezy, Robert L.
SO Herpetological Review
VL 46
IS 4
PS 501-505
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The xantusiid genus Lepidophyma is composed of 19 currently recognized
   species scattered from Nuevo Leon, Mexico south to Panama (Bezy and
   Camarillo 2002; Canseco-Marquez et al. 2008; Garcia-Vazquez et al.
   2010). Many of these are known from very few specimens and localities
   and their helminth parasites remain poorly known. Here we provide a
   summary of helminths reported from Lepidophyma and Cricosaura and
   discuss helminth parasitism in the Xantusiidae. We also report the
   results of a helminthological examination of Smith's Tropical Night
   Lizard, Lepidophyma, smithii Bocourt, 1876 (Fig. 1) from Chiapas,
   Mexico. This species is exceptional in the Xantusiidae in having a
   relatively broad ecological and latitudinal distribution, occurring in
   caves, rock crevices, and rotting logs along the Pacific versant from
   Guerrero, Mexico, south through Guatemala to El Salvador (Fig. 2) (Bezy
   and Camarillo 2002; Mendoza-Hernandez and Santos-Barrera 2004).
   Previously, the only helminths known from L. smithii are two species of
   Nematoda, Parapharyngodon guerreroensis Bursey and Goldberg, 2015 and
   third stage larvae of Physaloptera sp. found in specimens from Guerrero
   and Oaxaca (Bursey and Goldberg 2015).
C1 Goldberg, Stephen R.; Whittier Coll, Dept Biol, Whittier, CA, 90608,
   USA, USA.
EM sgoldberg@whittier.edu
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0018-084X
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts;
   Land zones; Nearctic region; Neotropical region; North America
DE Aplectana herediaensis [Reptilian hosts / Lepidophyma smithii / New
   record; prevalence] [Mexico / Chiapas / ]. 
   Cricosaura; Lepidophyma [Helminth parasites /  / Host parasite list]
   [Central America /  / ]. 
   Lepidophyma smithii [Nematode parasites / Aplectana herediaensis / New
   record; prevalence] [Mexico / Chiapas / ]. 
   Xantusiidae [Helminth parasites /  / Prevalence; overview] [Central
   America /  / distribution]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Nematodes; Reptiles; Vertebrates

   Sauria, Xantusiidae, Nematoda

   Cricosaura (Xantusiidae): [Host]. 
   Lepidophyma (Xantusiidae): [Host]. 
   Lepidophyma smithii (Xantusiidae): [Host; New record].

DT Article
TI Screening of tropical isolates of Metarhizium anisopliae (Hypocreales:
   Clavicipitaceae) for virulence to the sweet potato weevil, Cylas
   formicarius (Coleoptera: Brentidae).
AU Dotaona, Ronnie (rdotaona@csu.edu.au) 
   Wilson, Bree A.L.
   Stevens, Mark M.
   Holloway, Joanne
   Ash, Gavin J.
SO International Journal of Tropical Insect Science
VL 35
IS 4
PS 153-163
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 34
AB The sweet potato weevil (SPW), Cylas formicarius, is a serious pest of
   sweet potato in Australia and Papua New Guinea. Ten strains of
   Metarhizium sp. isolated from Australian soil samples were evaluated for
   their growth characteristics and screened for virulence to adult SPW
   under laboratory conditions. All isolates except QD62 (48.6%) had
   moderate to high germination (66-97%), and all took 2 to 4 days to
   sporulate at 25[degree]C. The optimal temperature for radial growth for
   the majority of isolates was 30[degree]C, and there was a significant
   interaction between isolate and temperature (P<0.05). Isolate QS155
   showed the fastest radial growth at 30[degree]C. The internal
   transcribed spacer sequences showed slight variations among the
   isolates; however, all isolates were shown to be Metarhizium anisopliae.
   Isolates varied greatly in their virulence. At 10 days after inoculation
   (DAI) by immersion in a suspension of 1x107conidia/ml, 9 of the 10
   isolates were virulent, causing 80-100% mortality of adult SPW. Only two
   isolates (QS001-6 and QS155) caused more than 50% mortality at 5 DAI. In
   dose-mortality bioassays, isolate QS155 had the lowest 20-day LC50 and
   LC90 values; however, there were no statistically significant
   differences in mortality among the three most promising isolates tested
   (QD66, QS001-6 and QS155). These results show that M. anisopliae isolate
   QS155 has potential as a microbial control agent for SPW, and that
   further evaluation under glasshouse and field conditions is warranted.
C1 Dotaona, Ronnie; Charles Sturt Univ, Graham Ctr Agr Innovat, Locked Bag
   588, Wagga Wagga, NSW, 2678, Australia, Australia.
EM rdotaona@csu.edu.au

OI Holloway, Jo/0000-0003-2742-4201; Ash, Gavin James/0000-0002-6703-8295;
   Stevens, Mark/0000-0002-7581-0783

PM 26486360
DT Article
TI The sexually dimorphic behaviour of adult Drosophila suzukii: elevated
   female locomotor activity and loss of siesta is a postmating response.
AU Ferguson, Calum T.J.
   O'Neill, Tara L.
   Audsley, Neil
   Isaac, R. Elwyn (r.e.isaac@leeds.ac.uk) 
SO Journal of Experimental Biology
VL 218
IS 23
PS 3855-3861
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 50
AB The polyphagous Drosophila suzukii is a highly invasive species that
   causes extensive damage to a wide range of berry and stone fruit crops.
   A better understanding of its biology and especially its behaviour will
   aid the development of new control strategies. We investigated the
   locomotor behaviour of D. suzukii in a semi-natural environment
   resembling a typical summer in northern England and show that adult
   female D. suzukii are at least 4-fold more active during daylight hours
   than adult males. This result was reproduced in several laboratory
   environments and was shown to be a robust feature of mated, but not
   virgin, female flies. Both males and virgin females kept on a 12 h
   light: 12 h dark (12LD) cycle and constant temperature displayed
   night-time inactivity (sleep) followed by weak activity in the morning,
   an afternoon period of quiescence (siesta) and then a prominent evening
   peak of activity. Both the siesta and the sharp evening peak at lights
   off were severely reduced in females after mating. Flies of either sex
   entrained in 12LD displayed a circadian pattern of activity in constant
   darkness confirming the importance of an endogenous clock in regulating
   adult activity. This response of females to mating is similar to that
   elicited in female Drosophila melanogaster by the male sex peptide (SP).
   We used mass spectrometry to identify a molecular ion (m/z, 5145)
   corresponding to the poly-hydroxylated SP of D. suzukii and to show that
   this molecule is transferred to the female reproductive tract during
   copulation. We propose that the siesta experienced by male and virgin
   female D. suzukii is an adaptation to avoid unnecessary exposure to the
   afternoon sun, but that mated females faced with the challenge of
   obtaining resources for egg production and finding oviposition sites
   take greater risks, and we suggest that the change in female behaviour
   is induced by the male SP.
C1 Isaac, R. Elwyn; Univ Leeds, Fac Biol Sci, Leeds, W Yorkshire, LS2 9JT,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM r.e.isaac@leeds.ac.uk
OI Audsley, Neil/0000-0002-7972-8656
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Behavioral Sciences; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology; Meteorology &Atmospheric Sciences
SN 0022-0949
BD Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Locomotion; Behaviour; Activity
   patterns; Abiotic factors; Physical factors
DE Drosophila suzukii [Sex differences / Sexual dimorphism / ] [Mating /  /
   ] [Locomotion / Locomotor activity / ] [Circadian activity /  / ] [Sleep
   / Siesta / ] [Temperature /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Drosophilidae

DT Article
TI Silicoflagellates and ebridians from the Seto Inland Sea and 111
   Kuroshio, including the description of Octactis pulchra var. takahashii
   var. nov.
AU Abe, Kenta (s14e101d@st.yamagatau.ac.jp) 
   McCartney, Kevin
   Fukunaga, Yuko
   Narita, Hisashi
   Jordan, Richard W.
SO Journal of Nannoplankton Research
VL 35
IS 2
PS 111-128
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three silicoflagellate species, Octactis pulchra, Dictyocha stapedia and
   Stephanocha speculum, and the ebridian Ebria tripartita, were observed
   in water samples from the Seto Inland Sea and the adjacent Kuroshio.
   Both Octactis and Dictyocha exhibit two distinct morphologies, with
   skeletons made of thicker components predominating in the Seto Inland
   Sea, and of thinner components in the Kuroshio. The skeletons of O.
   pulchra var. takahashii var. nov. have a more fragile appearance, with
   thinner components, longer spines and a smaller apical ring, compared to
   basal ring diameters, than the better known type variety O. pulchra var.
   pulchra. Both thick and thin forms of Octactis and Dictyocha were often
   found as double skeletons, with skeletons of Octactis apparently
   attached at the abbasal surfaces of the basal corners by organic matter,
   while those of Dictyocha were held in place by pikes. Only one specimen
   of S. speculum and a small number of ebridians were observed in the Seto
   Inland Sea, with both being absent in the Kuroshio samples.

EM s14e101d@st.yamagatau.ac.jp

DT Article
TI MOLECULAR AND MORPHOLOGICAL EVIDENCE DEMONSTRATING TWO SPECIES OF
   HELICOMETRINA LINTON 1910 (DIGENEA: OPECOELIDAE) IN NORTHERN CHILE.
AU Oliva, Marcelo E. (marcelo.oliva@uantof.cl) 
   Valdivia, Isabel M.
   Chavez, Rosa A.
   Molina, Horacio
   Cardenas, Leyla
SO Journal of Parasitology
VL 101
IS 6
PS 694-700
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 1
U2 10
AB The opecoelid Helicometrina nimia Linton, 1910 has been reported from
   numerous marine fishes along the Pacific and Atlantic coasts of the
   Americas. Along the Chilean coast, H. nimia is found in fishes belonging
   to at least 9 families. This surprisingly low host specificity of H.
   nimia raises question about the correct identification of specimens
   assigned to this species. Here we evaluate whether H. nimia specimens
   isolated from sympatric fish species in northern Chile but with
   different diets and found in different habitats (water column and
   demersal) are the same species. Our results demonstrate that specimens
   from the shallow benthic fish Labrisomus philippii (Steindachner) do not
   correspond to H. nimia but instead belong to a new species of
   Helicometrina. This species is described and distinguished from H. nimia
   using morphological descriptions and 2 molecular markers (the cytochrome
   c oxidase subunit 1 gene and the V4 region of the SSU rRNA gene). The
   new species Helicometrina labrisomi (Digenea: Opecoelidae), is found in
   the intestine of L. philippii (Steindachner, 1866) (Pisces:
   Labrisomidae), a shallow benthic fish that inhabits the northern coast
   of Chile. We also studied the related Helicometrina nimia Linton, 1910
   from the benthopelagic fishes Paralabrax humeralis (Valenciennes, 1828)
   and Acanthistius pictus (Tschudi, 1846) (Serranidae). The new species
   differs from H. nimia by a combination of characters that include ovary
   shape, number of uterine loops, and position of the genital pore. Our
   results indicate that morphological characteristics, such as body size,
   extent of the vitellarium, shape of the testes, and cirrus sac size and
   extent, traditionally used in the taxonomy of Helicometrina are highly
   variable. In contrast, meristic and morphological characteristics, such
   as a lobed ovary, the number of uterine loops, dimensions of the
   pharynx, and the opening of the genital pore, are highly constant.
C1 Oliva, Marcelo E.; Univ Antofagasta, Fac Ciencias Mar & Recursos Biol,
   POB 170, Antofagasta, Chile, Chile.
EM marcelo.oliva@uantof.cl

OI Cardenas, Leyla/0000-0003-0676-6704; Oliva, Marcelo

DT Article
TI Helminth Parasites of Juvenile Green Turtles Chelonia mydas (Testudines:
   Cheloniidae) in Brazil.
AU Werneck, M.R. (max@bwvet.com.br) 
   Silva, R.J.
SO Journal of Parasitology
VL 101
IS 6
PS 713-716
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB The present study offers a parasitological analysis of juvenile
   individuals of the green turtle (Chelonia mydas) found on the Brazilian
   coast between 2004 and 2011. Helminths were found in 90 out of 136
   individuals (66.2%, CI = 57.7-74.0). In total, 29,411 helminths were
   collected, belonging to the families Brachycoeliidae, Cladorchiidae,
   Microscaphidiidae, Pronocephalidae, Rhytidodidae, and Spirorchiidae.
   Mean species richness was 4.74 (CI = 4.03-5.46), the mean intensity was
   327 (CI = 223-489), and the mean abundance was 216 (CI = 146-339). This
   study also reports new geographical records for: Angiodictyum longum,
   Angiodictyum parallelum, Rameshwarotrema uterocrescens, Pyelosomum
   cochlear, Schizamphistomum scleroporum, Cymatocarpus solearis, and
   Neospirorchis sp. This is the first analysis of helminth composition in
   juveniles of green turtles

DT Article
TI Integrative taxonomic description of Plakina kanaky, a new polychromatic
   sponge species from New Caledonia (Porifera: Homoscleromorpha).
AU Ruiz, Cesar
   Ivanisevic, Julijana
   Chevaldonne, Pierre
   Ereskovsky, Alexander V.
   Boury-Esnault, Nicole
   Vacelet, Jean
   Thomas, Olivier P.
   Perez, Thierry (thierry.perez@imbe.fr) 
SO Marine Ecology
VL 36
IS 4
PS 1129-1143
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Four similar sponges of different colors, all unknown to science, were
   collected in submarine caves of New Caledonia. We aimed at determining
   whether the four chromotypes represented different species or phenotypic
   variations of a unique new species. We used an integrative taxonomic
   approach combining morphologic, molecular and metabolomic analyses. The
   main traits that define these specimens are a skeleton made of
   monolophose, trilophose and tetralophose calthrops only, high chemical
   diversity and a high abundance and diversity of prokaryotic symbionts.
   The symbiotic community includes two unique prokaryote morphotypes,
   which are described for the first time in Homoscleromorpha, and appeared
   to be vertically transmitted. Although several features slightly differ
   among chromotypes, the most parsimonious conclusion was to propose a
   single new species Plakina kanaky sp. nov. Our phylogenetic analysis
   indicated the paraphyly of the Plakina genus, with P. kanaky sp. nov.
   belonging to a clade that includes Plakina jani and Plakina trilopha.
   The present work demonstrates that integrative taxonomy should be used
   in order to revise the entire Plakinidae family and especially the
   non-monophyletic genus Plakina.
C1 Perez, Thierry; Univ Avignon, Aix Marseille Univ, Rue Batterie Lions,
   Marseille, F-13007, France, France.
EM thierry.perez@imbe.fr

   Ivanisevic, Julijana/E-3519-2017
OI Ereskovsky, Alexander/0000-0003-1079-7204; THOMAS,
   Olivier/0000-0002-5708-1409; Ivanisevic, Julijana/0000-0001-8267-2705

DT Article
TI Trachelipus species (Crustacea, Isopoda, Oniscidea) in Romanian fauna:
   morphology, ecology, and geographic distribution.
AU Tomescu, Nicolae (ntonescu@hasdeu.ubbcluj.ro) 
   Teodor, Lucian Alexandru
   Ferenti, Sara
   Covaciu-Marcov, Severus-Daniel
SO North-Western Journal of Zoology
VL 11
SU 1
PS S1-S106
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB Specific morphological characters are re-described in 12 species of
   Trachelipus genus, found in Romanian fauna: T. trilobatus (Stein, 1859),
   T. afar (Budde-Lund, 1896), T. varae (Radu, 1949), T. ratzeburgii
   (Brandt, 1833), 2'. bujori (Radii, 1950), T. difficilis (Radii, 1950),
   T. affinis (Koch, 1841) = T. wachtleri (Strouhal, 1851), 2'. arcuatus
   (Budde-Lund, 1885), T. rathkii (Brandt, 1833), 2'. pleonglandulatus
   (Radu, 1950), T. nodulosus (Koch, 1838), T. squamuliger (Verhoeff,
   1907). Descriptions are illustrated with figures for all characters. The
   species, which were synonymised in the past, are described comparatively
   (T. varae and T. afar, T. bujori and T. ratzeburgii, T. difficilis and
   T. affinis = T. wachtleri, T. pleonglandulatus and T. rathkii). The
   comparative descriptions emphasize that the synonymised species are
   valid. The variations of some morphological characters and morphological
   anomalies observed on the studied specimens are noted in each species.
   Data on the species distribution in Romania and on their ecology are
   also presented. In the case of the five endemic species in Romania (T.
   trilobatus, T. afar, T. varae, T. bujori, T. pleonglandulatus) new
   distribution localities are reported. T. squamuliger was encountered for
   the first time in the country, in Dobruja.

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15204023439
