PT J
AN ZOOR15303016623
DT Article
TI New associations between Phasiinae (Diptera: Tachinidae) and
   Pentatomidae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) phytophagous insects in the
   rolling pampa (Argentina) and description of Dallasimyia bosqi Blanchard
   male.
FT Nuevas asociaciones entre Phasiinae (Diptera: Tachinidae) y Pentatomidae
   (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) fitofagos en la pampa ondulada (Argentina) y
   descripcion del macho de Dallasimyia bosqi Blanchard.
AU Liljesthrom, Gerardo G. (gerardo@cepave.edu.ar) 
   Avalos, Delia S.
SO Revista de la Sociedad Entomologica Argentina
VL 75
IS 3-4
PS 145-152
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The relationships between Phasiinae (Diptera: Tachinidae) parasitoid
   flies and their Pentatomidae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera) hosts are little
   known in Argentina. We present new host-parasitoid associations in the
   rolling pampa, and describe for the first time the adult male of
   Dallasimyia bosqi Blanchard. Adult Hemiptera were sampled biweekly
   during spring-summer 2005, 2006 and 2012 in areas of natural vegetation
   and crops of red clover and soybean, in fields in La Plata, Magdalena
   and Chivilcoy counties (Buenos Aires province). The Hemiptera were
   reared under controlled conditions; those with parasitoid macrotype eggs
   stuck on the corium were kept till death, and those with no signs of
   parasitism were kept for up to 25-30 days. Each dead host was placed in
   a container with damp soil and covered with a nylon mesh. The adult
   parasitoids emerged were conditioned for identification. Five new
   associations were recorded: E. meditabunda - Cilindromyia brasiliana
   (Townsend) and Homogenia sp., D. furcatus - Trichopoda argentinensis
   (Blanchard) and Dallasimyia bosqi, and C. armigera - Trichopoda
   giacomellii (Blanchard) as well as the already known N. viridula -
   Trichopoda giacomellii. Reference collections are deposited in the Museo
   de La Plata, Argentina (MCNLP) and in the Museu de Zoologia da
   Universidade de Sao Paulo, Brazil (MZSP).
C1 Liljesthrom, Gerardo G.; Univ Nacl La Plata, Ctr Estudios Parasitol &
   Vectores CEPAVE, Calle 2 584, La Plata, Buenos Aires, RA-1900,
   Argentina, Argentina.
EM gerardo@cepave.edu.ar
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0373-5680
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Habitat;
   Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Chinavia armigera [Dipteran parasites / Trichopoda giacomellii / New
   record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Cylindromyia brasiliana; Trichopoda argentinensis [Hemipteran hosts /
   Dichelops furcatus / New record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Dallasimyia bosqi; Homogenia [Hemipteran hosts / Edessa meditabunda /
   New record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Dichelops furcatus [Dipteran parasites / Cylindromyia brasiliana / New
   record] [ / Trichopoda argentinensis / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Edessa meditabunda [Dipteran parasites / Dallasimyia bosqi / New record]
   [ / Homogenia / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Pentatomidae [Dipteran parasites / Phasiinae / Host parasite list; new
   record] [Grassland / Rolling pampas habitat / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Phasiinae [Hemipteran hosts / Pentatomidae / Host parasite list; new
   record] [Grassland / Rolling pampas habitat / ] [Argentina /  / ]. 
   Trichopoda giacomellii [Hemipteran hosts / Chinavia armigera / New
   record] [Argentina /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Bugs; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Tachinidae, Hemiptera, Heteroptera, Pentatomomorpha, Pentatomoidea,
   Pentatomidae
OR Cylindromyia brasiliana (Tachinidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Dallasimyia bosqi - Blanchard (Tachinidae): [First time described, Male,
   p. 148; Parasite; New record]. 
   Homogenia (Tachinidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Phasiinae (Tachinidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Trichopoda argentinensis (Tachinidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Trichopoda giacomellii (Tachinidae): [Parasite; New record]. 
   Pentatomidae (Pentatomoidea): [Host; New record]. 
   Chinavia armigera (Pentatomidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Dichelops furcatus (Pentatomidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Edessa meditabunda (Pentatomidae): [Host; New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15303016623
OA DOAJ Gold

AN ZOOR15303016231
DT Article
TI Two new species of Idris Foerster (Hymenoptera: Platygastridae) from
   Southeastern Brazil, parasitoids of Argyrodes elevatus Walckenaer
   (Araneae: Theridiidae) and Scytodes sp (Araneae: Scytodidae).
AU Margaria, Cecilia (cmargaria@fcnym.unlp.edu.ar) 
   Loiacono, Marta
   Gonzaga, Marcelo O.
   Aquino, Daniel
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 17
IS 2
PS 159-166
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this study two new species of Idris Foerster (Platygastridae) are
   described and illustrated: I. argyrodes sp. nov. and I. scytodes sp.
   nov., from specimens reared from eggs of the spider species Argyrodes
   elevatus Walckenaer (Theridiidae) and Scytodes sp. (Scytodidae)
   collected in Minas Gerais State, Brazil. Scytodidae is a new host family
   for Idris.
C1 Margaria, Cecilia; Museo La Plata, Paseo Bosque S-N, La Plata, Buenos
   Aires, RA-1900, Argentina, Argentina.

DT Article
TI Description of the spider Verita williamsi, a new genus and species from
   Santa Fe, Argentina (Araneae, Gnaphosidae).
AU Ramirez, Martin J. (ramirez@macn.gov.ar) 
   Grismado, Cristian J.
SO Revista del Museo Argentino de Ciencias Naturales
VL 17
IS 2
PS 173-182
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Verita williamsi, new genus and species (Araneae, Gnaphosidae) is
   described from specimens recently collected in Northern Santa Fe
   Province, Argentina. The peculiar combination of having only two
   piriform gland spigots, aligned setae on the leg scopulae, and anterior
   lateral spinnerets not widely spaced suggests that the species is
   probably a close relative of Micaria and some of the small
   representatives of the Anzacia group of genera. It differs from all of
   them by having three teeth in the cheliceral retromargin and lacking
   iridescent squamose scales in the abdomen.
C1 Ramirez, Martin J.; Museo Argentino Ciencias Nat Bernardino Rivadavia,

   Argentina, Argentina.

PT J

PM 27019734
DT Article
TI A new Early Oligocene toothed 'baleen' whale (Mysticeti: Aetiocetidae)
   from western North America: one of the oldest and the smallest.
AU Marx, Felix G. (felix.marx@otago.ac.nz) 
   Tsai, Cheng-Hsiu
   Fordyce, R. Ewan
SO Royal Society Open Science
VL 2
IS 12
PS 150476
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 17
AB Archaic toothed mysticetes represent the evolutionary transition from
   raptorial to bulk filter feeding in baleen whales. Aetiocetids, in
   particular, preserve an intermediate morphological stage in which teeth
   functioned alongside a precursor of baleen, the hallmark of all modern
   mysticetes. To date, however, aetiocetids are almost exclusively Late
   Oligocene and coeval with both other toothed mysticetes and fully
   fledged filter feeders. By contrast, reports of cetaceans from the Early
   Oligocene remain rare, leaving the origins of aetiocetids, and thus of
   baleen, largely in the dark. Here, we report a new aetiocetid, Fucaia
   buelli, from the earliest Oligocene (ca 33-31 Ma) of western North
   America. The new material narrows the temporal gap between aetiocetids
   and the oldest known mysticete, Llanocetus (ca 34 Ma). The specimen
   preserves abundant morphological detail relating to the phylogenetically
   informative ear bones (otherwise poorly documented in this family), the
   hyoid apparatus and much of the (heterodont) dentition. Fucaia comprises
   some of the smallest known mysticetes, comparable in size with the
   smallest odontocetes. Based on their phylogenetic relationships and
   dental and mandibular morphology, including tooth wear patterns, we
   propose that aetiocetids were suction-assisted raptorial feeders and
   interpret this strategy as a crucial, intermediary step, enabling the
   transition from raptorial to filter feeding. Following this line of
   argument, a combination of raptorial and suction feeding would have been
   ancestral to all toothed mysticetes, and possibly even baleen whales as
   a whole.
C1 Marx, Felix G.; Natl Museum Nat & Sci, Dept Geol & Palaeontol, Tsukuba,
   Ibaraki, Japan, Japan.
EM felix.marx@otago.ac.nz
OI Marx, Felix Georg/0000-0002-1029-4001
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 2054-5703; 2054-5703
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean; Geological time periods;
   Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene
DE Fucaia [Oligocene /  / New genus]. 
   Fucaia buelli [North Pacific / USA, Washington / new species] [Oligocene
   /  / ]. 
TN Cetaceans; Chordates; Mammals; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Cetacea, Aetiocetidae
OR Chonecetus goedertorum (Cetacea): [Referred to, New genus Fucaia, p. 4].
   
   Fucaia (Aetiocetidae): [Gen nov, Type species Fucaia buelli, p. 3,
   Oligocene; Fossil]. 
   Fucaia buelli (Aetiocetidae): [Sp nov, USA, Washington (marine),
   Oligocene, P. 4; Fossil]. 
   Fucaia goedertorum (Aetiocetidae): [Comb nov, Transferred from
   Chonecetus, p. 4]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15407040829
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15407040833
PM 27019740
DT Article
TI Peculiar macrophagous adaptations in a new Cretaceous pliosaurid.
AU Fischer, Valentin (v.fischer@ulg.ac.be) 
   Arkhangelsky, Maxim S.
   Stenshin, Ilya M.
   Uspensky, Gleb N.
   Zverkov, Nikolay G.
   Benson, Roger B.J.
SO Royal Society Open Science
VL 2
IS 12
PS 150552
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB During the Middle and Late Jurassic, pliosaurid plesiosaurs evolved
   gigantic body size and a series of craniodental adaptations that have
   been linked to the occupation of an apex predator niche. Cretaceous
   pliosaurids (i.e. Brachaucheninae) depart from this morphology, being
   slightly smaller and lacking the macrophagous adaptations seen in
   earlier forms. However, the fossil record of Early Cretaceous
   pliosaurids is poor, concealing the evolution and ecological diversity
   of the group. Here, we report a new pliosaurid from the Late Hauterivian
   (Early Cretaceous) of Russia. Phylogenetic analyses using reduced
   consensus methods recover it as the basalmost brachauchenine. This
   pliosaurid is smaller than other derived pliosaurids, has tooth alveoli
   clustered in pairs and possesses trihedral teeth with complex serrated
   carinae. Maximum-likelihood ancestral state reconstruction suggests
   early brachauchenines retained trihedral teeth from their ancestors,
   butmodified this feature in a uniqueway, convergent with macrophagous
   archosaurs or sphenacodontoids. Our findings indicate that Early
   Cretaceous marine reptile teeth with serrated carinae cannot be
   unequivocally assigned to metriorhynchoid crocodylomorphs. Furthermore,
   they extend the known diversity of dental adaptations seen in
   Sauropterygia, the longest lived clade of marine tetrapods.
C1 Fischer, Valentin; Univ Oxford, Dept Earth Sci, Oxford, OX1 3AN, United
   Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM v.fischer@ulg.ac.be
RI Zverkov, Nikolay/P-2293-2015
OI Zverkov, Nikolay/0000-0002-9731-1977; Fischer,
   Valentin/0000-0002-8808-6747; Benson, Roger/0000-0001-8244-6177
SC Zoology
SN 2054-5703; 2054-5703
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Makhaira [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Makhaira rossica [Russia /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Euryapsida, Sauropterygia
OR Makhaira (Sauropterygia): [Gen nov, Of Thalassophonea, Type species
   Makhaira rossica, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Makhaira rossica (Sauropterygia): [Sp nov, Russia, Cretaceous, P. 3;
   Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15407040833
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published

AN ZOOR15403010457
DT Article
TI Description of Llosaria bilobulata gen. et sp. nov. (Bivalvia:
   Gastrochaenidae), a new endobenthic mollusc from the late Miocene of
   Minorca (Balearic Islands, Western Mediterranean).
FT Descripcion de Llosaria bilobulata gen. et sp. nov. (Bivalvia:
   Gastrochaenidae), un nuevo molusco endobentico del Mioceno de Menorca
   (Islas Balearas, Mediterraneaneo occidental).
AU Quintana Cardona, Josep (picoguevo@hotmail.com) 
SO Spira
VL 5
IS 4
PS 153-161
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new, relatively large, gastrochaenid bivalve genus is described mostly
   on the basis of its calcareous tube morphology, which is characterized,
   at the proximal end, by the presence of two distinct lobes in the
   ventral margin. This feature enables the separation of the new genus
   from other gastrochaenids. The reconstruction of the valves is merely
   hypothetical, since in most specimens the shell is either hidden by the
   calcareous tube or has almost disappeared (in some cases, only part of
   the umbo is preserved). This suggests that the two valves are thin and
   fragile. To date, Llosaria bilobulata gen. et sp. nov. has been found
   only on the surface separating the bottom of a calcarenitic layer with
   abundant bioclasts and macrofossils, from the top of another
   calcarenitic layer with abundant pebbles, apparently with no
   macrofossils. At the boundary between these two sedimentary units, L.
   bilobulata gen. et sp. nov. is represented by numerous individuals,
   mostly juveniles in their life positions. This suggests that this
   bivalve was one of the first organisms to colonize this habitat, once
   the seemingly adverse conditions that existed when the calcarenitic
   sediments with abundant pebbles were deposited. Llosaria bilobulata gen.
   et sp. nov. is considered to be an endobenthic bivalve that lived
   partially covered by substratum, inside of non-hardened sediments, as
   indicated by the skeletons of some epibiont organisms (cirripedes and
   bryozoans), as well as the dolomitic pebbles and shell fragments
   embedded in the calcareous tube. (C) Associacio Catalana de Malacologia
   (2015)
C1 Quintana Cardona, Josep; Univ Autonoma Barcelona, Inst Catala Paleontol
   Miquel Crusafont, Edifici ICTA ICP,Carrer Columnes S-N,Campus UAB,
   Barcelona, E-08193, Spain, Spain.
EM picoguevo@hotmail.com
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1577-7952
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Spain; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Neogene
DE Llosaria [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
   Llosaria bilobulata [Balearic Islands /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ].
   
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Myoida, Gastrochaenoidea
OR Llosaria (Gastrochaenoidea): [Gen nov, Of family Gastrochaenidae, Type
   species Llosaria bilobulata, p. 157, Miocene; Fossil]. 
   Llosaria bilobulata (Gastrochaenoidea): [Sp nov, Balearic Islands,
   Miocene, P. 157; Fossil].

TI Moitessieriids (Gastropoda: Moitessieriidae) from Monistrol de
   Montserrat (el Bages, Catalonia, Spain).
FT Els moitessieriids (Gastropoda: Moitessieriidae) de Monistrol de
   Montserrat (el Bages, Catalunya, Espanya).
AU Tarruella, Antoni
   Corbella, Jordi
   Prats, Lluis
   Guillen, Gloria
   Alba, David M. (david.alba@icp.cat) 
SO Spira
VL 5
IS 4
PS 163-180
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA Catalan
U1 0
U2 0
AB Moitessieriids (Mollusca: Gastropoda) from two the springs of Monistrol
   de Montserrat (el Bages, Catalonia) are described based on conchological
   material. Three different species are identified: Moitessieria olleri,
   Moitessieria punctata and Moitessieria tatirocae sp. nov. The new
   species is characterized, among other features, by a large,
   subcylindrical and very slender shell with pits. The new citations of M.
   punctata and M. olleri, in turn, increase the known geographical
   distribution of these species. (C) Associacio Catalana de Malacologia
   (2015)
C1 Alba, David M.; Univ Autonoma Barcelona, Inst Catala Paleontol Miquel
   Crusafont, Edifici ICTA ICP,Carrer Columnes S-N,Campus UAB, Barcelona,
   E-08193, Spain, Spain.

DT Article
TI Presence of genus Bryopa Gray, 1847 (Bivalvia: Clavagellidae) in the
   late Miocene of Minorca (Balearic Islands, Western Mediterranean).
FT Presencia del genere Bryopa Gray, 1847 (Bivalvia: Clavagellidae) en el
   Mioce superior de Menorca (Illes Balears, Mediterrania occidental).
AU Quintana Cardona, Josep (picoguevo@hotmail.com) 
SO Spira
VL 5
IS 4
PS 187-192
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA Catalan
U1 0
U2 0
AB The calcareous tubes and the associated internal molds of a fossil
   bivalve from the detrital and bioclastic level (oolithic level) of Cala
   en Basto (late Miocene), which is located in the southwest of Ciutadella
   de Menorca (Balearic Islands), are described. The calcareous tubes are
   characterized by the absence of tubules. In the internal molds, the
   ventral margins of the two valves are in contact throughout its length.
   The position of the inner mold suggests that the right valve was
   cemented to the calcareous tube. All these characters together enable
   the attribution of these speciments to the clavagellid Bryopa sp., which
   is reported for the first time in the Neogene of Menorca. The need to
   review, from a taxonomic viewpoint, some specimens from the Miocene of
   Mallorca previously assigned to Clavagella brocchii or Clavagella sp.,
   but very similar to the Minorcan fossils, is further discussed. (C)
   Associacio Catalana de Malacologia (2015)
C1 Quintana Cardona, Josep; Carrer Gustau Mas 79,1er, Ciutadella De
   Menorca, Illes Balears, 07760, Spain, Spain.
EM picoguevo@hotmail.com

SN 1577-7952

TI MACROCHELID MITES (ACARI: MESOSTIGMATA) ASSOCIATED WITH DUNG BEETLES IN
   BALURAN NATIONAL PARK, EAST JAVA, INDONESIA.
AU Hartini, Sri (srihartini_mzb@yahoo.com) 
   Dwibadra, Dhian
   Ohara, Masahiro
   Takaku, Gen
SO Treubia
VL 42
PS 23-36
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Eight mite species of the family Macrochelidae (Acari: Mesostigmata)
   were collected from the body surface of dung beetles in Baluran National
   Park, East Java, Indonesia. Of these, one species, Macrocheles
   subwallacei sp. nov., is described as new to science. The female of
   Macrocheles crispa (Berlese, 1910) is redescribed and the male is
   described for the first time. The remaining six species are Neopodocinum
   jaspersi (Oudemans, 1900), M. dispar (Berlese, 1910), M. hallidayi
   Walter & Krantz, 1986, M. entetiensis Hartini & Takaku, 2005, M.
   jabarensis Hartini & Takaku, 2003 and M. persimilis Hartini, Dwibadra &
   Takaku, 2007.

TI MACROCHELID MITES (ACARI: MESOSTIGMATA) FROM KAIMANA, WEST PAPUA,
   INDONESIA, AND ENDEMISM OF MACROCHELID MITE FAUNA IN NEW GUINEA ISLAND.
AU Hartini, Sri (srihartini_mzb@yahoo.com) 
   Takaku, Gen
SO Treubia
VL 42
PS 53-67
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of our investigation in Lengguru, Kaimana, West Papua,
   Indonesia, six species belonging to two genera of macrochelid mites
   (Acari: Mesostigmata: Macrochelidae) were collected from the body
   surface of dung beetles (Scarabaeidae). Of these, one is undescribed
   species Macrocheles kaimanaensis sp. nov. Macrocheles hallidayi Walter &
   Krantz, 1986 is newly recorded from Papua and West Papua (Indonesian
   parts of New Guinea Island). Males of Holostaspella rosichoni Hartini &
   Takaku, 2006 originally described from Papua were recorded for the first
   time. The other three species were M. amaliae Hartini, 2008, M. dispar
   (Berlese, 1910) and M. waigeoensis Hartini, 2008, which were previously
   collected from Raja Ampat, West Papua.

TI Drosophila curviceps Species-Group (Diptera: Drosophilidae) from India,
   with Description of a New Species and Redescription of a Known Species.
AU Pradhan, Sushmika
   Sati, Pradeep C.

U2 5
AB The Drosophila curviceps species subgroup is upgraded to a species-group
   independent from the Drosophila immigrans species group to which it has
   belonged, but its subgeneric assignment is still undetermined, i.e.,
   incertae sedis. A new species, Drosophila teresae Pradhan & Sati, sp.

   India is described, and supplementary and revised description for
   Drosophila muktesh-warensis Joshi et al. (Entomon (India) 30: 75-84,

PT J

PM 26623428
DT Article
TI A Checklist of Iranian Cockroaches (Blattodea) with Description of
   Polyphaga sp as a New Species in Iran.
AU Hashemi-Aghdam, Saedeh Sadat
   Oshaghi, Mohammad Ali (moshaghi@sina.tums.ac.ir) 
SO Journal of Arthropod-Borne Diseases
VL 9
IS 2
PS 161-175
PD Dec 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 78
AB Background: Cockroaches are of vital importance medically and
   hygienically. They are able to contaminate foods and act as vectors of
   pathogenic agents such as bacteria, Protozoa, and parasites to human
   environment either mechanically or through their digestive system.
   Cockroaches belong to the phylum Arthropoda, class Insecta, and order
   Blattodea or Blattaria. To date, over 4,500 cockroach species have been
   reported from different parts of the world. We overviewed the documents
   involved Iranian cockroaches to up-to-date checklist of cockroach
   species distributed in various provinces of Iran. Methods: An extensive
   literature review was performed in 2013 on Iranian handbooks, reports
   and published data available since 1986 to obtain a comprehensive list
   of Iranian cockroaches. Furthermore, in an entomological survey in
   Tehran, cockroach specimens were collected and identified based on
   morphological and the DNA sequences of the mitochondrial cytochrome
   oxidase subunit II (COII) gene (mt-DNA COII) characteristics. Results:
   Morphological characterization revealed presence of an un-described
   species very similar to Polyphaga aegyptiaca, P. indica and somehow to
   Pycnoscelus surinamensis, however, supplementary molecular analysis
   revealed the species was associated with Polyphaga of Corydiidae
   (Polyphagidae). With regards to the report of the un-described species,
   the cockroach fauna of Iran includes three families, 14 genera, and 26
   species. Conclusion: Some species has not been collected or reported
   recently and also many geographical regions of the country have not been
   studied yet, hence a systematic research is required to reveal the real
   cockroach list of the country. Geographical distributions, nomination
   changes, and synonyms of cockroach species are presented.
C1 Oshaghi, Mohammad Ali; Tehran Univ Med Sci, Sch Publ Hlth, Tehran, Iran,
   Iran.
EM moshaghi@sina.tums.ac.ir
RI Oshaghi, Mohammad A/H-8373-2016
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
BD Systematics; Documentation; Publications; General morphology; Genetics;
   Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Blattodea [Checklists / Distributional & taxonomic checklist / ]
   [Literature review /  / ] [General morphology / Morphological
   characteristics / ] [Molecular genetics / mtDNA sequencing / ]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogenetic analysis / ] [Iran /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Dictyoptera
OR Blattodea (Dictyoptera).

PT J
AN ZOOR15211068325
PM 26412142
DT Article
TI Circulation of Dirofilaria repens, Setaria tundra, and Onchocercidae
   species in Hungary during the period 2011-2013.
AU Kemenesi, Gabor
   Kurucz, Kornelia
   Kepner, Anett
   Dallos, Bianka
   Oldal, Miklos
   Herczeg, Robert
   Vajdovics, Peter
   Banyai, Krisztian
   Jakab, Ferenc (jakabf@gamma.ttk.pte.hu) 
SO Veterinary Parasitology
VL 214
IS 1-2
PS 108-113
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Dirofilaria repens and recently Dirofilaria immitis are known to be
   endemic in Hungary. Since there is no related research on Dirofilaria
   carrier mosquito species from Hungary, we conducted a three-year
   mosquito surveillance study between 2011 and 2013. During the study
   period we examined 23,139 female mosquitoes with a generic
   filaria-specific TaqMan PCR assay, and characterized them by sequencing
   a 500 bp segment of 125 rRNA. An important result of our study was the
   detection of Setaria tundra and D. repens along with an unidentified
   Onchocercidae nematode. D. repens is known to be endemic in Hungary,
   however, the detection of S. tundra in all sampling sites throughout the
   study period indicates for the first time the endemicity of this
   parasite in Hungary. The Onchocercidae sp. nematode showed 95%
   nucleotide identity with previously detected unidentified nematodes from
   Germany, indicating a broader geographical distribution of this nematode
   in Europe. D. immitis specific DNA was not detected among the screened
   mosquitoes in this study. Here we report 11 mosquito species as
   potential vector organisms for local filarial infections, including
   Aedes vexans, Ochlerotatus annulipes, Ochlerotatus sticticus,
   Coquillettidia richiardii, Anopheles hyrcanus and Ochlerotatus rusticus.
   Dirofilaria development unit was calculated and the potential
   transmission period was estimated, which ranged between 65 and 113 days
   between sampling seasons. A relatively high infection rate (36.8%) was
   identified, which is a notable finding for veterinary and human health
   professionals. Moreover, the results of our study widen the group of
   possible mosquito vector species for D. repens and S. tundra in Central
   Europe. (C) 2015 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Jakab, Ferenc; Univ Pecs, Virol Res Grp, Ifjusag Ut 20, Pecs, H-7624,
   Hungary, Hungary.
EM jakabf@gamma.ttk.pte.hu
RI Jakab, Ferenc/B-1536-2016
OI Banyai, Krisztian/0000-0002-6270-1772; Kurucz,
   Kornelia/0000-0001-6190-1265; Kemenesi, Gabor/0000-0001-9775-3065
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Genetics
   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0304-4017
BD Genetics; Evolution; Parasites diseases and disorders; Transmission;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe

PT J
AN ZOOR15206035259
DT Article
TI Taxonomic Study on the cirrus Group of Genus Stenus Latreille
   (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae), with Descriptions of Three New Species from
   Japan.
AU Naomi, Shun-Ichiro (naostenus@hb.tp1.jp) 
   Ito, Tateo
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 207-215
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This is the 53rd study on the subfamily Steninae (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae) from Japan; and the Stenus cirrus group is taxonomically
   treated, including descriptions of three new species S. yamabusi (Ehime
   and Kochi Prefs.), S. caesariatus (Kyoto, Hyogo and Tottori Prefs.) and
   S. rasilis (Ehime Pref.) and redescription of a rare, known species S.
   yashiro Naomi et Puthz, 1994. The taxonomically important characters are
   illustrated in detail for the species treated in this paper. A taxonomic
   problem regarding the S. domburi Hromadka, 1979a (cirrus group) and S.
   tanuki Hromadka, 1979b (indubius group) is discussed. Stenus
   longisetosits Puthz, 1993 is newly placed in synonym with S. domburi
   Hromadka, 1979a. Stenus tanuki Hromadka is resurrected as a distinct
   species (but not as a synonym of S. indubius Sharp, 1889); and S.
   wakayamanus Puthz, 2001 is newly placed in synonym with S. tanuki
   Hromadka, 1979b. In addition, a key to the Japanese species of cirrus
   group is provided for identification.
C1 Naomi, Shun-Ichiro; Nat Hist Museum & Inst, Chuo Ku, Aoba Cho 955-2,
   Chiba, 2608682, Japan, Japan.

   species]. 
   Stenus cirrus group [Japan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Systematics]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae

   Stenus cirrus group (Staphylinidae): [Key to species, Japan, P. 213].

   longisetosus Puthz 1993, p. 212]. 
   Stenus indubius - Sharp 1889 (Staphylinidae): [Removal from synonymy,
   Stenus tanuki Hromadka 1979, p. 213]. 
   Stenus rasilis (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 213].

   wakayamanus Puthz 2001, p. 213; Removal from synonymy, With Stenus

TI Taxonomic Study on the Genus Stenus Latreille (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Steninae), with Descriptions of Five New Species from
   Japan.
AU Naomi, Shun-Ichiro (naostenus@hb.tp1.jp) 
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 217-224
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This is the 54th taxonomic study on the subfamily Steninae (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae) from Japan, with descriptions of five new species of the
   genus Stenus Latreille. The new species of Stenus described herein are
   as follows: S. abbreviatus (western part of Japan), S. recurvatus
   (Okinawa Pref.), S. leehermani (Gifu Pref.), S. brevispinus (Shizubka
   Pref.), and S. yoshitomii (Ehime Pref.). The taxonomically important
   characters including several posterior abdominal segments, aedeagus,
   endophallic structures and spermatheca are illustrated in detail for the
   species treated in this paper.

DT Article
TI A New Hainokisaruzo (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) Discovered from a Taiwan
   Beech Forest in Mt. Taipingshan, Taiwan.
AU Yoshitake, Hiraku (zoumushi@niaes.affrc.go.jp) 
   Lu, Sheng-Shan
   Lee, Chi-Feng
   Ito, Motomi
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 235-239
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Hainokisaruzo Yoshitake et Colonnelli is
   described from Taiwan under the name of Hainokisaruzo formosanus sp.
   nov. In addition to general taxonomic information on the present new
   species, DNA barcodes are provided for three individuals including the
   holotype. Hainokisaruzo formosanus is similar in general appearance to
   H. gressitti Korotyaev from Chiayi County, Taiwan, but is easily
   distinguishable from H. gressitti by having the armed femora and the
   simple female ventrite V neither with projection nor depression. Adults
   of H. formosanus were found on Symplocos arisanensis (Symplocaceae)
   growing in a Taiwan beech forest.

   Ctr, 3-1-3 Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 3058604, Japan, Japan.

TI Revision of the Flower Fly Genus Mallota Meigen, 1822 (Diptera:
   Syrphidae) from Japan.
AU Hirooka, Takuto
   Maruyama, Munetoshi (dendrolasius@gmail.com) 
   Thompson, F. Christian
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 241-258
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Japanese species of the flower fly genus Mallota Meigen are revised,
   and 13 species are recognized, of which two are new species: M. spinosa
   Hirooka & Maruyama, sp. nov. and M thompsoni Hirooka & Maruyama, sp.
   nov. The following species are synonymized: Imatisma dimorpha Shiraki,
   1930 (M dimorpha), syn. nov. (with M eristaliformis Sack, 1910);
   Imatisma ambiguum Shiraki, 1968 (M ambigua), syn. nov., M shirakii Peck,
   1985, syn. nov. and M yakushimana Kassebeer, 1996, syn. nov. (with M
   rubripes Matsumura, 1916). Key to the Japanese species is given. Habitus
   photographs and illustration of male genitalia of all the species are
   provided.

   Ohbayashi, Nobuo

VL 21
IS 2
PS 291-296
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Mimonemophas Breuning, 1961 is synonymized with Anoplophora
   Hope, 1839. Anoplophora cheni sp. nov. is described from Yunnan, China.
   Anoplophora quadrifasciatus (Breuning, 1961), comb. nov. is newly
   recorded from China. Endophallus in inflated and everted condition of A.
   quadrifasciatus is compared with A. wusheana Chang, 1961. Illustrations
   of the habitus and diagnostic features are provided.

   Yoloides Guignot, 1960 of the genus Pachynectes Regimbart, 1903 is
   transferred to Yolina Guignot, 1936. Yoloides is proposed as a junior

DT Article
TI Revision of the Genus Dexagria Rohdendorf, 1978 (Diptera: Sarcophagidae:
   Paramacronychiinae).
AU Verves, Yury (fly_@voliacable.com) 
   Xue, Wan-Qi
   Wang, Ping
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 337-343
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A review of the genus Dexagria with a key to species are presented. This
   genus belonging to the subfamily Paramacronychiinae is distributed in
   Central and East Asia and four species were recognized. A new species,
   Dexagria sinuata Xue, Verves and Wang, is described, a new combination,
   Dexagria ussuriensis (Pape, 1998), is proposed and the genus Primorya
   Pape, 1998 is synonymized with Dexagria Rohdendorf, 1978. Furthermore,
   the genus Cattasoma Reihard, 1947 is transferred from the subtribe
   Dexaqgriina to the subtribe Agriina and the members of the subfamily
   Paramacronychiinae are listed. Key words: Paramacronychiinae, Dexagria,
   new species, key, composition.
C1 Verves, Yury; Natl Acad Sci Ukraine, Inst Evolutionary Ecol, Acad
   Lebedev Str 37, Kiev, UA-03143, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM fly_@voliacable.com
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160

   Taxonomic position; Key; Documentation; Publications; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Dexagria [Asia / Central-east / Distribution; taxonomic review]. 
   Dexagria sinuata [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
   Paramacronychiinae [Checklists /  / ] [ / Taxonomic checklist / ] [Asia
   / Central-east / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Sarcophagidae

   Dexaqgriina, p. 343]. 
   Dexagria - Rohdendorf 1978 (Sarcophagidae): [Syn nov, Primorya Pape
   1998, p. 337; Key to species, P. 340].

   Yunnan, P. 337].

   Transferred from Primorya, p. 340].

   Dexagria, p. 340].

DT Article
TI Review of the genus Heteroderes Latreille in Japan (Coleoptera:
   Elateridae: Agrypninae).
AU Arimoto, Koichi (elateridbeetle@gmail.com) 
   Tsukada, Taku
   Arimoto, Hisayuki
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 345-350
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of the genus Heteroderes Latreille, 1834 are confirmed in
   Japan. Heteroderes kusuii Ohira, 1994 is synonymized with H. amplicollis
   (Gyllenhal, 1817), which is widely distributed in the New World,
   Polynesia and Micronesia. Heteroderes changi Ohira, 1967 was originally
   described from Taiwan, and is recorded from Japan for the first time
   with a supplemental description. The two species are regarded as alien
   species introduced by human activity. Heteroderes inexpectatus Kishii,
   1969 is also probably an introduced species, although it was originally
   described from eastern Honshu, Japan. A key to Heteroderes species
   inhabiting Japan is given.
C1 Arimoto, Koichi; Kyushu Univ, Grad Sch Bioresource & Bioenvironm Sci,
   Fukuoka, 8128581, Japan, Japan.
EM elateridbeetle@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 1341-1160
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Description; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Heteroderes [Japan /  / Key to species] [ /  / Distribution; taxonomic
   review]. 
   Heteroderes changi [Japan /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Elateroidea,
   Elateridae
OR Heteroderes - Latreille 1834 (Elateridae): [Key to species, Japan, P.
   349]. 
   Heteroderes amplicollis - (Gyllenhal 1817) (Elateridae): [Syn nov,
   Heteroderes kusuii Ohira 1994, p. 345]. 
   Heteroderes changi - Ohira 1967 (Elateridae): [Redescription, P. 347;
   New record].

TI New Record of Plecia longiforceps Duda, 1934 from Yaeyama Islands, Japan
   (Diptera: Bibionidae).
AU Fitzgerald, Scott J. (woodyfitz@gmail.com) 
   Nakamura, Takeyuki
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 351-354
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Plecia longiforceps Duda, 1934, is recorded from Yaeyama Islands
   (Yonaguni, Iriomote and Ishigaki Islands), Japan for the first time.
   This is the sixth species of the genus recorded from Japan. Plecia
   sinensis Hardy, 1953, previously only known from mainland China, is
   found to be a junior synonym of P. longiforceps.

TI Arthropod Galls Newly Found on the Izu Islands, Tokyo, Japan.
AU Tokuda, Makoto (tokudam@cc.saga-u.ac.jp) 
   Kawauchi, Kouta
   Kikuchi, Takeshi
   Iwasaki, Yumi
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 363-365
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During field surveys on the Izu Islands, Tokyo, Japan from 2011 to 2014,
   a fruit gall induced by Asphondylia sp. (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) on
   Gardneria nutans (Loganiaceae) was discovered and a stem gall induced by
   Eucosma metzneriana (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae) on Altemisia indica var.
   maximowiczii was newly recorded from the Izu Islands. In addition,
   several cecidomyiid and other arthropod galls were newly recorded from
   Niijima, Shikinejima, Miyakejima, Hachijojima, and Aogashima Islands.
C1 Tokuda, Makoto; Saga Univ, Fac Agr, Honjo 1, Saga, 8408502, Japan,
   Japan.

TI Records of Scarabaeoid Beetles from Ludao Is., Taiwan (Coleoptera:
   Scarabaeoidea).
AU Kobayashi, Hirokazu
   Masumoto, Kimio
   Sakai, Kaoru
   Yoshitake, Hiraku (zoumushi@niaes.affrc.go.jp) 
   Ito, Motomi
SO Japanese Journal of Systematic Entomology
VL 21
IS 2
PS 367-372
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A list of eighteen scarabaeoid species collected from Ludao Is., Taiwan,
   is provided. One of which, Holotrichia sp., is undetermined at this
   time. The following six species are recorded for the first time from the
   island: 1) Parascatonomus acuticollis, 2) Rhyparus loebli, 3) Rhyparus
   helophoroides, 4) Anomala siniopyga, 5) Papuana philippinica, and 6)
   Dipelicus deiphobus loi.

   Ctr, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 3058604, Japan, Japan.

DT Article
TI Two new Thopeutica species from the Philippines (Coleoptera: Carabidae:
   Cicindelinae).
AU Wiesner, Juergen (juergen.wiesner@wolfsburg.de) 
SO Mitteilungen des Internationalen Entomologischen Vereins E.V. Frankfurt
   A.M.
VL 40
IS 1-2
PS 1-8
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Thopeutica (Thopeutica) anichtchenkoi n. sp.is described from Mindanao,
   Mt. Apo. It is characterised by the metallic ground colour of the elytra
   and the stout shape of the aedeagus. Thopeutica (Thopeutica)
   hinabanganensis n. sp.is described from Samar, Central Visayas. It is
   characterised by the blackish green colour of the elytra, the shallow
   microscultpure of the elytra and the shape of the aedeagus.
C1 Wiesner, Juergen; Dresdener Ring 11, Wolfsburg, D-38444, Germany,
   Germany.

TI A new Therates species from China (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Cicindelinae).
AU Wiesner, Juergen (juergen.wiesner@wolfsburg.de) 
SO Mitteilungen des Internationalen Entomologischen Vereins E.V. Frankfurt
   A.M.
VL 40
IS 1-2
PS 43-47
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Therates turnai n. sp. is described from China, Guizhou province. It is
   distinguished from the similar Th. csorbai Wiesner, 1999 by the pale
   labrum, shape of elytran humeral lunule and shape of aede-agus. A key to
   the Chinese species of the Th. chennelli species-group is given.

   Germany.

PT J
AN ZOOR15205031645
DT Article
TI [New Contributions to the Fauna of Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) of Arabian
   Peninsula and Socotras.]
FT Neue Beitrage zur Fauna der Bostrichidae (Coleoptera) der Arabischen
   Halbinsel und Sokotras.
AU Geis, Klaus-Ulrich (kontakt@kaeferklaus.de) 
SO Mitteilungen des Internationalen Entomologischen Vereins E.V. Frankfurt
   A.M.
VL 40
IS 1-2
PS 63-101
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB Analysis of more than 770 specimens of Coleoptera Bostrichidae from
   different countries of the Arabian Peninsula and the island of Socotra
   resulted in a total of 31 species of this family. 7 species are recorded
   from the Subregion for the first time. Along with the first species
   records of 21 species from Oman, another 6 new species records from
   Saudi Arabia, 2 and 7 new species records from Yemen and Socotra,
   respectively, are listed. Bostrychoplites normandi ssp. yemenensis
   Lesne, 1935 is elevated to species level and positioned in the new genus
   Bostrychoplectron gen. nov., together with two closely related species.
   All finds are listed together with indications of zoogeography,
   distribution, host plants and, when appropriate, economic importance.
C1 Geis, Klaus-Ulrich; Bohlstr 4, Freiburg, D-79115, Germany, Germany.
EM kontakt@kaeferklaus.de

AN ZOOR15204024260
DT Article
TI Two new species of the genus Cleora Curtis (Ennominae, Geometridae),
   closely related to C-repetita (Butler), from Sumatra and West New
   Guinea, Indonesia.
AU Sato, Rikio
SO Tinea
VL 23
IS 3
PS 135-141
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the genus Cleora Curtis are described from Indonesia.
   C. brevipecten sp. nov. is so far endemic to Sumatra and C. kobayashii
   sp. nov. is distributed in the western part of New Guinea. They are
   closely related to C. repetita (Butler), which has been known in the
   Indo-Australian tropics from Sundaland to the Solomons and Australia.
   Further revisional study will be needed to clarify the taxonomic status
   of each population of the "C. repetita"-complex.
C1 Sato, Rikio; 2-27-29 Shindori Nishi,Nishi Ku, Niigata, 9502036, Japan,
   Japan.
SC Zoology
SN 0493-3168
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Cleora brevipecten; Cleora kobayashii [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; Lepidopterans
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Lepidoptera, Glossata, Heteroneura,
   Geometroidea, Geometridae
OR Cleora brevipecten (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 135]. 
   Cleora kobayashii (Geometridae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 138].

DT Article
TI Anorthoa plumbeata (Hreblay et Ronkay, 1998), stat. nov., (Noctuidae,
   Hadeninae), a bona species endemic to Taiwan, with notes of immature
   stages.
AU Owada, Mamoru (owada@kahaku.go.jp) 
   Wu, Shipher
   Fu, Chien -Ming
   Huang, Han-Yau
   Yamamoto, Mitsundo
SO Tinea
VL 23
IS 3
PS 171-176
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Anorthoa plumbeata (Hreblay et Ronkay, 1998), stat. nov., is separated
   from Eurasian species, Anorthoa munda (Denis et Schiffermuller, 1775),
   and regarded as a distinct, endemic species in Taiwan. The male and
   female genitalia and immature stages of A. plumbeata are illustrated for
   the first time.

DT Article
TI Taxonomic revision and cladistic analysis of the Neotropical genus
   Acrochaeta Wiedemann, 1830 (Diptera: Stratiomyidae: Sarginae).
AU Fachin, Diego Aguilar (diegoafachin@gmail.com) 
   Amorim, Dalton De Souza
SO Zootaxa
VL 4050
IS 1
PS 1-110
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB The Neotropical genus Acrochaeta Wiedemann is revised and a cladistics
   analysis of the genus based on morphological characters is presented.
   This paper raises the total number of extant Acrochaeta species from 10
   to 14 with the description of nine new species, the synonymy of one
   species, the transfer of five species to other genera and the transfer
   of one species of Merosargus to Acrochaeta. The new species described
   (of which eight are from Brazil and one from Bolivia and Peru) are
   Acrochaeta asapha nov. sp., A. balbii nov. sp., A. dichrostyla nov. sp.,
   A. Polychaeta nov. sp., A. pseudofasciatanov. sp., A. pseudopolychaeta
   nov. sp., A. rhombostyla nov. sp. A. ruschii nov. sp. and A. stigmata
   nov. sp. The primary-types of all Acrochaeta species were studied at
   least from photos, when possible with the study of dissected male or
   female terminalia. A. mexicana Lindner is proposed as a junior synonym
   of A. flaveola Bigot. M. chalconota (Brauer) comb. nov., M. degenerata
   (Lindner) comb. nov., M. longiventris (Enderlein) comb. nov. and M.
   picta (Brauer) comb. nov. are herein transferred from Acrochaeta to
   Merosargus Loew, and Chrysochlorina elegans (Perty) comb. nov. is
   transferred from Acrochaeta to Chrysochlorina James. A. convexifrons
   (McFadden) comb. nov. is transferred from Merosargus to Acrochaeta. The
   limits of the genus and its insertion in the Sarginae are considered,
   and an updated generic diagnosis is provided. All species of the genus
   are redescribed and diagnosed, and illustrated with photos of the
   habitus, thorax, wing, and drawings of the antenna and male and female
   terminalia. Distribution maps are provided for the species, along with
   an identification key for adults of all species. Parsimony analyses were
   carried out under equal and implied weight. Our matrix includes 43
   terminal taxa-of which 26 are outgroup species from four different
   sargine genera-and 59 adult morphological characters. The phylogenetic
   analysis supports the monophyly of Acrochaeta based on features of the
   head, thorax and abdomen. An inner clade (Acrochaeta flaveola species
   group) within the genus was clearly recovered based on characters of
   male and female terminalia. There is good evidence for the paraphyly of
   Merosargus with Acrochaeta as a subclade, demanding a wider study of the
   subfamily for a sound solution for the genus Merosargus.
C1 Fachin, Diego Aguilar; Univ Sao Paulo, Fac Filosofia Ciencias & Letras
   Ribeirao Preto, Av Bandeirantes 3900, Ribeirao Preto, SP, BR-14040901
   BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM diegoafachin@gmail.com
RI Fachin, Diego Aguilar/V-8034-2018
OI Fachin, Diego Aguilar/0000-0001-6018-9886
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; General
   morphology; Evolution; Land zones; Neotropical region; South America

DT Article
TI Redescription of some species of Bryozoa described by J. Jullien and L.
   Calvet in the NE Atlantic.
AU Reverter-Gil, Oscar (oscar.reverter@usc.es) 
   Souto, Javier
SO European Journal of Taxonomy
VL 157
PS 1-17
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Five species described by Jullien and/or Calvet from the NE Atlantic are
   redescribed and stabilized by typification: Hippothoa amoena,
   Schizoporella confusa, S. jullieni, S. ovum and Smittia guernei. Three
   new synonymies are established: Schizoporella jullieni with Hippothoa
   amoena, S. ovum with Escharina alderi, and Escharella pseudopunctata
   with Smittia guernei. A new trypostegid genus, Pulpeirina gen. nov., is
   erected for H. amoena. Three new combinations are introduced.
C1 Reverter-Gil, Oscar; Univ Santiago de Compostela, Fac Biol, Santiago De
   Compostela, 15782, Spain, Spain.
EM oscar.reverter@usc.es
OI Souto Derungs, Javier/0000-0003-0791-2590
SC Zoology
SN 2118-9773

   Diagnosis; Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Bryozoa [North Atlantic / East / Systematics; taxa described by Jullien
   & Calvet]. 
TN Bryozoans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Bryozoa

   Spelling, P. 5]. 
   Pulpeirina (Bryozoa): [Gen nov, Of family Trypostegidae, Type species
   Hippothoa amoena Jullien & Calvet 1903, p. 2].

TI An annotated catalogue and bibliography of the taxonomy, synonymy and
   distribution of the Recent Vetigastropoda of South Africa (Mollusca).
AU Herbert, David G. (dherbert@nmsa.org.za) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4049
IS 1
PS 1-98
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A complete inventory of the known Recent vetigastropod fauna of South
   Africa is provided. Bibliographic citations to works discussing the
   taxonomy, synonymy and distribution of the species in a southern African
   or south-western Indian Ocean context are provided. Additional
   explanatory notes are given where pertinent. New genus records for South
   Africa: Acremodontina B.A. Marshall, 1995; Choristella Bush, 1879;
   Cocculinella Thiele, 1909; Conjectura Finlay, 1926; Crosse la Iredale,
   1924; Falsimargarita Powell, 1951; Lepetella Verrill, 1880;
   Profundisepta McLean & Geiger, 1998; Stomatella Lamarck, 1816; Stomatia
   Helbling, 1779; Stomatolina Iredale, 1937; Synaptocochlea Pilsbry, 1890;
   Tibatrochus Nomura, 1940; Visayaseguenzia Poppe, Tagaro & Dekker, 2006;
   Zetela Finlay, 1926. New species records for South Africa: Acremodontina
   aff. carinata Powell, 1940; Anatoma finlayi (Powell, 1937);
   Anatomamunieri (P. Fischer, 1862); Calliotropis acherontis B.A.
   Marshall, 1979; Calliotropis bucina Vilvens, 2006; Cocculinella
   minutissima (E.A. Smith, 1904); Diodora ruppellii (G.B. Sowerby (I),
   1835); Emarginula costulata Deshayes, 1863; Emarginula decor ata
   Deshayes, 1863; Jujubinus hubrechti Poppe, Tagaro & Dekker, 2006;
   Lepetella sp.; Seguenzia orientalis Thiele, 1925; Stomatella auricula
   Lamarck, 1816; Stomatia phymotis Helbling, 1779; Stomatolina angulata
   (A. Adams, 1850); Stomatolina cf. calliostoma (A. Adams, 1850);
   Stomatolina aff. danblumi Singer & Mienis, 1999; Stomatolina cf rubra
   (Lamarck, 1822); Stomatolina sp.; Synaptocochlea concinna (Gould, 1845);
   Tectus mauritianus (Gmelin, 1791); Tibatrochus cf. incertus (Schepman,
   1908); Turbo imperials Gmelin, 1791; Turbo tursicus Reeve, 1848;
   Visayaseguenzia compsa (Melvill, 1904). New species: Spectamen martensi,
   replacement name for Spectamen semisculptum sensu Herbert (1987) (non
   Martens, 1904). New name: Oxystele antoni is proposed as a new name for
   Trochus (Turbo) variegatus (non Gmelin, 1791 =Heliacus) Anton, 1838.
   Revised taxonomy: Cyclostrema semisculptum Martens, 1904 is an earlier
   name for Solariella intermissa Thiele, 1925, and is referable to the
   genus Zetela Finlay, 1926; Margarita bicarinata A. Adams & Reeve, 1850
   is considered to be a senior synonym of Solariella undata G.B. Sowerby
   (II), 1870, and is referable to the genus Ilanga Herbert, 1987.
   Validation of the name Trochus tigrinus Chemnitz, 1781 is credited to
   Dillwyn (1817) rather than Anton (1838). New synonyms: Clanculus
   exquisita Turton, 1932 =Calliostom a africanum Bartsch, 1915;
   Cyclostrema alfredensis Bartsch, 1915 =I' arviturbo alfredensis
   (Bartsch, 1915); Cynisca gloriosa Bartsch, 1915 =Cinysca spuria (Gould,
   1861); Herbertina hayesi Herbert, 1995 =Bruceina chenoderma (Barnard,
   1963); Ilanga millardi Herbert, 1987 =Ilanga humillima (Thiele, 1925);
   Leptothyra africana Bartsch, 1915 =Cinysca spuria (Gould, 1861);
   Leptothyr a albocincta Turton, 1932 =Tricolia striolata (Turton, 1932);
   Solariella undata G.B. Sowerby (II), 1870, S. gratiosa Thiele, 1925 and
   S. valdiviae Thiele, 1925 =Ilanga bicarinata bicarinat a (A. Adams &
   Reeve, 1850); Solariella chuni Thiele, 1925, S. intermiss a Thiele,
   1925, S. gilchristi Barnard, 1963 and S. macleari Barnard, 1963 =Zetela
   semisculpta (Martens, 1904); Turbo (ColIonia) armillatus G.B. Sowerby
   (III), 1886 =Cinysca spuria (Gould, 1861). New combinations: Basilissa
   (Ancistrobasis) compsa Melvill, 1904 is transferred to Visayaseguenzia;
   Calcar rhysopoma Barnard, 1964 is transferred to Bothropoma; Calliostoma
   glaucophaos Barnard, 1963 is transferred to Falsimargarita; Calliotropis
   chenoderma Barnard, 1963 is transferred to Bruceina; Collonia bicarinata
   Martens, 1902 is transferred to Cinysca; Crossea agulhasensis Thiele,
   1925 is transferred to Conj ectur a; Cyclostrema semisculptum Martens,
   1904 is transferred to Zetela; Cyclostremella farica Bartsch, 1915 is
   transferred to Dikoleps; Cynisca africana Bartsch, 1915 is transferred
   to Homalopoma; Leptogyra africana: Bartsch, 1915 is transferred to
   Cirsonella; Leptothyra agulhasensis Thiele, 1925 is transferred to
   Homalopom a; Leptothyr a alfredensis Bartsch, 1915 is transferred to P
   arviturbo; Leptothyr a sola Barnard, 1963 is transferred to a
   Parviturbo; Liotia (Cynisca) semiclausa Thiele, 1925 is transferred to
   Cinysca; Monilea spuria Gould, 1861 is transferred to Cinysca; Monodonta
   gibbula Thiele, 1925 is transferred to Cantrainea; Puncturella
   voraginosa Herbert & Kilburn, 1986 is transferred to Profundisepta;
   Solariella fuscomaculata GB. Sowerby (III), 1892 is transferred to
   Skenea; Solariella turbynei Barnard, 1963 is transferred to Zetela;
   Turbo boswellae Barnard, 1969 is transferred to Cantrainea; Turbo
   foveolatus Barnard, 1963 is transferred to Crosseola; Turbo ponsonbyi
   G.B. Sowerby (III), 1897 is transferred to Bothropoma; Vitrinella
   agulhasensis Thiele, 1925 is transferred to Parviturbo; Vitrinella
   (Docomphala) arifca Bartsch, 1915 is transferred to Lodderena;
   Vitrinella inclinans Barnard, 1963 is transferred to Skenea.

   ZA-3200, South Africa, South Africa.

TI First record of the invasive bee Anthidium manicatum (Hymenoptera:
   Megachilidae) in Chile.
AU Montalva, Jose (montalva.jose@yahoo.es) 
   Rios, Mauro
   Vivallo, Felipe
SO Journal of Melittology
VL 56
PS 1-5
PD Nov 30 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Palearctic wool carder bee Anthidium manicatum (Linnaeus) is
   recorded for the first time in Chile based on eight specimens collected
   on Lavandula sp. (Lamiaceae) in San Bernardo, Metropolitan Region. This
   new record expands the invasive range of this species in South America,
   confirming previous predictions based on an ecological niche model.

DT Article
TI The scarab beetle tribe Pentodontini (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae:
   Dynastinae) of Colombia: taxonomy, natural history, and distribution.
AU Lopez-Garcia, Margarita M. (margaralopezg@gmail.com) 
   Gasca-Alvarez, Hector J.
   Amat-Garcia, German
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 451-492
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB Pentodontini is the most diverse tribe of Dynastinae (Coleoptera:
   Scarabaeidae), and most of the genera are restricted to a single
   biogeographic region. In this work, the taxonomic composition of the
   Pentodontini in Colombia was determined, and genera and species were
   diagnosed based on external morphology and male genitalia. Records of
   1,580 specimens from 31 departments and 398 localities in Colombia were
   obtained from 24 species in the genera Bothynus Hope, Denhezia
   Dechambre, Euetheola Bates, Hylobothynus Ohaus, Oxyligyrus Arrow,
   Parapucaya Prell, Pucaya Ohaus, and Tomarus Erichson. Oxyligyrus
   cayennensis Endrodi, Tomarus cicatricosus (Prell), and T. pullus (Prell)
   are reported for the first time from Colombia. Pucaya punctata Endrodi
   is reduced to synonymy with Pucaya pulchra Arrow. Possible changes in
   the classification of Denhezia Dechambre are discussed. Dichotomous keys
   are provided for Colombian genera and species. Taxonomic descriptions
   and distribution maps are included for all species.
C1 Lopez-Garcia, Margarita M.; Univ Nacl Colombia, Inst Ciencias Nat,
   Bogota, Colombia, Colombia.
EM margaralopezg@gmail.com
RI Gasca, Hector/AAJ-1525-2020
OI Gasca, Hector/0000-0002-0070-0715
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Land zones; Neotropical region; South America
DE Bothynus; Euetheola; Hylobothynus; Oxyligyrus; Parapucaya; Pucaya;

   Oxyligyrus cayennensis; Tomarus cicatricosus; Tomarus pullus [Colombia /

   Melyridae, Scarabaeoidea, Scarabaeidae
OR Parapucaya - Prell 1934 (Melyridae): [Key to species, Colombia, Adults,
   p. 469]. 
   Bothynus - Hope 1837 (Scarabaeidae): [Key to species, Colombia, Adults,
   p. 456]. 
   Denhezia - Dechambre 2006 (Scarabaeidae): [Taxonomic position, Incertae
   sedis, p. 461]. 
   Euetheola - Bates 1888 (Scarabaeidae): [Key to species, Colombia,
   Adults, p. 461]. 
   Hylobothynus - Ohaus 1910 (Scarabaeidae): [Key to species, Colombia,

DT Article
TI Confused identity: subgenera of Pseudoeudesis Binaghi belong in two
   tribes (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae: Scydmaeninae).
AU Jaloszynski, Pawel (scydmaenus@yahoo.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 493-507
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Afroeudesis Franz and Oreoeudesis Franz, Afrotropical subgenera of
   Pseudoeudesis Binaghi (Scydmaenini), are elevated to the genus rank and
   transferred to Cyrtoscydmini. The East Palaearctic genus Nanoscydmus
   Jaloszynski is reduced to a subgenus of Afroeudesis stat. n., resulting
   in Afroeudesis (Nanoscydmus) baoshanus (Jaloszynski), comb. n. and
   Afroeudesis (Nanoscydmus) nepalensis (Jaloszynski), comb. n.
   Morphological structures of the type species of Afroeudesis and
   Oreoeudesis are illustrated and described in detail, and the following
   species are redescribed: Afroeudesis (s. str.) basilewskyi Franz
   (Tanzania), Oreoeudesis lindneri Franz (Tanzania), Oreoeudesis
   aberdarensis Franz (Kenya) and Oreoeudesis camerunensis Franz
   (Cameroon).
C1 Jaloszynski, Pawel; Univ Wroclaw, Museum Nat Hist, Sienkiewicza 21,
   Wroclaw, PL-50335, Poland, Poland.
EM scydmaenus@yahoo.com
OI Jaloszynski, Pawel/0000-0003-2973-1803

SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334

   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates

   Scydmaenidae

DT Article
TI Benthic Ostracods of Skogsbergiella (Myodocopina: Cylindroleberididae)
   from the Southern Ocean.
AU Chavtur, Vladimir G.
   Keyser, Dietmar (keyser@zoologie.uni-hamburg.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 508-522
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Skogsbergiella tetrathrix sp. nov. and S. species A, species of the
   family Cylindroleberididae are described from the Drake Passage
   (59[degree]21.97'S-60[degree]4.27'W to
   59[degree]22.55'S-60[degree]4.01'W, depth 2372-2380 m) and Weddell Sea
   (75[degree]49.9'S-27[degree]31.7'W to
   74[degree]51.55'S-27[degree]40.3'W, depth 467-475m) respectively.
   Skogsbergiella tetrathrix sp. nov. is very close to S. macrothrix
   Kornicker, 1975 but differs by greater size of carapace, 2-jointed
   rod-shaped organ, lesser number of setae on comb of fifth limb and teeth
   on combs of seventh limb, and absence of lateral eyes. S. species A is
   similar to S. skogsbergi Kornicker, 1971 and S. senex Kornicker, 1996
   but differs in size and number of setae on the dorsal margin of
   mandibular basale and seventh limb.
C1 Keyser, Dietmar; Univ Hamburg, Biozentrum Grindel & Zool Museum,
   Hamburg, D-20146, Germany, Germany.
EM keyser@zoologie.uni-hamburg.de
RI Chavtur, Vladimir Grigoryevich/AAG-2457-2019
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Key; Marine
   zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Skogsbergiella [Antarctic Ocean / Weddell Sea / Systematics]. 
   Skogsbergiella tetrathrix [South Atlantic /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Ostracoda
OR Skogsbergiella - Poulsen 1965 (Ostracoda): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 521; Key to species, P. 509]. 
   Skogsbergiella tetrathrix (Ostracoda): [Sp nov, South Atlantic, P. 510].

DT Article
TI Antocha crane flies from Taiwan (Diptera: Limoniidae: Limoniinae).
AU Podenas, Sigitas (sigitas.podenas@ekoi.lt) 
   Young, Chen W.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 523-537
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Taiwanese species of the crane fly subgenus Antocha (Antocha) Osten
   Sacken, 1860, are reviewed. Antocha (Antocha) taiwanensis, new species,
   is described and figured. Previously known species, Antocha (A.) bifida
   Alexander, 1924a and Antocha (A.) styx Alexander, 1930 are redescribed
   and illustrated. Antocha (A.) javanensis Alexander, 1915 is removed from
   the list of Taiwanese crane flies. Antocha (A.) gracillima Alexander,
   1924b and species close to Antocha (A.) streptocera Alexander, 1949 are
   listed for the first time in Taiwan. Identification key for all
   Taiwanese Antocha species is given.
C1 Podenas, Sigitas; Vilnius Univ, Dept Zool, Ciurlionio Str 21-27,
   Vilnius, LT-08412, Lithuania, Lithuania.
EM sigitas.podenas@ekoi.lt
OI Podenas, Sigitas/0000-0002-2597-566X

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia

   Antocha (Antocha) gracillima [Taiwan /  / New record]. 
   Antocha (Antocha) javanensis [Taiwan /  / Removal from faunal list]. 
   Antocha (Antocha) taiwanensis [Taiwan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Limoniidae

TI New World species of Asymphyloptera Collin (Diptera: Empididae:
   Clinocerinae).
AU Sinclair, Bradley J. (bradley.sinclair@inspection.gc.ca) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 553-564
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Eight species are recognized among New World species of Asymphyloptera
   Collin, including seven new species (A. cajanuma sp. nov. (Ecuador), A.
   chilensis sp. nov. (Chile), A. chiricahua sp. nov. (USA: Arizona), A.
   dominica sp. nov. (Dominica), A. havasu sp. nov. (USA: Arizona), A.
   lutea sp. nov. (Costa Rica) and A. mexicana sp. nov. (Mexico)). The new
   species are described, male terminalia illustrated, distributions mapped
   and a key to species is presented. Two additional undescribed species
   based on single females, are known from Ecuador and Venezuela.

   Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.

TI Lethe gregoryi Watkins (Lepidoptera, Nymphalidae, Satyrinae), a distinct
   species.
AU Lang, Song-Yun (langsongyun@gmail.com) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 4
PS 575-582
PD Nov 27 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In this paper, Lethe helle gregoryi Watkins, 1927 is raised to specific
   status, viz. L. gregoryi stat. nov., and L. moelleri bitaensis Yoshino,
   1999 syn. nov. is found to be a junior synonym of gregoryi. Lethe
   gesangdawai Huang, 2001 is sunk to a subspecies of L. gregoryi, viz. L.
   gregoryi gesangdawai stat. nov.

   gregoryi gesangdawai, p. 576].

   bitaensis Yoshino 1999, p. 576; Raised from, Lethe helle gregoryi, p.

TI Review of Platyplastinx Enderlein, 1937 (Diptera, Psychodidae) with
   descriptions of four new species.
AU Lopes, Priscila Silva (lopes_biologa@yahoo.com.br) 
   Bravo, Freddy
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048

LA English

AB Platyplastinx Enderlein, with eight previously described species, is
   currently known to occur in the southeastern United States, Costa Rica,
   Ecuador and Brazil. Four new species from Brazil are described:
   Platyplastinx amazonensis sp. nov., P. duckhousei sp. nov., P. exiguus
   sp. nov. and P. hirsutus sp. nov. Platyplastinx obscurus (Bravo, Lago &
   Castro, 2004) comb. n. is transferred from Alepia. The generic diagnosis
   is updated, global species are listed, and an identification key for
   males of all species is provided. Thirteen species are now known, eight
   of which are described from Brazil.

   chinensis Li & van Achterberg, sp. nov. is described and illustrated. It
   was reared from Agrilus sp. (Coleoptera: Buprestidae), a twig-boring
   pest of Caragana korshinskii Kom. (Leguminosae) in Inner Mongolia
   Autonomous Region, NW China. A key to the East Palaearctic species of
   the genus Leluthia is provided.

DT Article
TI Armored kinorhynch-like scalidophoran animals from the early Cambrian.
AU Zhang, Huaqiao (hqzhang@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Xiao, Shuhai
   Liu, Yunhuan
   Yuan, Xunlai
   Wan, Bin
   Muscente, A.D.
   Shao, Tiequan
   Gong, Hao
   Cao, Guohua
SO Scientific Reports
VL 5
PS 16521
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 3
U2 36
AB Morphology-based phylogenetic analyses support the monophyly of the
   Scalidophora (Kinorhyncha, Loricifera, Priapulida) and Nematoida
   (Nematoda, Nematomorpha), together constituting the monophyletic
   Cycloneuralia that is the sister group of the Panarthropoda. Kinorhynchs
   are unique among living cycloneuralians in having a segmented body with
   repeated cuticular plates, longitudinal muscles, dorsoventral muscles,
   and ganglia. Molecular clock estimates suggest that kinorhynchs may have
   diverged in the Ediacaran Period. Remarkably, no kinorhynch fossils have
   been discovered, in sharp contrast to priapulids and loriciferans that
   are represented by numerous Cambrian fossils. Here we describe several
   early Cambrian ([approximately]535 million years old) kinorhynch-like
   fossils, including the new species Eokinorhynchus rarus and two unnamed
   but related forms. E. rarus has characteristic scalidophoran features,
   including an introvert with pentaradially arranged hollow scalids. Its
   trunk bears at least 20 annuli each consisting of numerous small
   rectangular plates, and is armored with five pairs of large and
   bilaterally placed sclerites. Its trunk annuli are reminiscent of the
   epidermis segments of kinorhynchs. A phylogenetic analysis resolves E.
   rarus as a stem-group kinorhynch. Thus, the fossil record confirms that
   all three scalidophoran phyla diverged no later than the Cambrian
   Period.
C1 Zhang, Huaqiao; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol,
   Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.
EM hqzhang@nigpas.ac.cn
RI Xiao, Shuhai/A-2190-2009
OI Xiao, Shuhai/0000-0003-4655-2663
SC Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 2045-2322
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Evolution; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; China; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Eokinorhynchus [Cambrian /  / New genus]. 
   Eokinorhynchus rarus [Sichuan /  / new species] [Cambrian /  / ]. 
   Scalidophora [Phylogeny /  / Systematics] [Shaanxi / Xixiang / ]
   [Sichuan / Nanjiang County, Xinli / ] [Cambrian / Early Cambrian / ]. 
TN Invertebrates
ST Animalia
OR Eokinorhynchus (Animalia): [Gen nov, Of Scalidophora, Type species
   Eokinorhynchus rarus, p. 2, Cambrian; Fossil]. 
   Eokinorhynchus rarus (Animalia): [Sp nov, Sichuan, Cambrian, P. 2;
   Fossil]. 
   Scalidophora (Animalia): [Fossil]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15210061260
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

PT J
AN ZOOR15202012367
PM 26624752
DT Article
TI A revision of the genus Tambana Moore, 1882 with description of eight
   new species and one subspecies (Lepidoptera, Noctuidae: Pantheinae).
   Revision of Pantheinae, contribution XIII.
AU Behounek, G.
   Han, H.L.
   Kononenko, V.S. (gottfried.behounek@t-online.de) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 3
PS 301-351
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The oriental Pantheinae genus Tambana Moore, 1882 (type-species Tambana
   variegata Moore, 1882) with 16 previously described species is revised.
   Eight new species and one subspecies (T. tibetica sp. n., T. xilinga sp.
   n., T. mekonga sp. n., T. helmuti sp. n., T. fansipana sp. n., T. laura
   sp. n., T. indeterminata sp. n., T. annamica sp. n., T. annamica stumpfi
   ssp. n.) are described from China, Vietnam and Myanmar. One unrecognized
   taxon is included to the revision. Three new synonyms and one new
   combination are introduced (Trisuloides klapperichii Mell 1958, syn. n.
   of Tambana entoxantha (Hampson, 1894); Tambana behouneki Speidel &
   Kononenko, 1998, syn. n. of Tambana glauca (Hampson, 1898); Trichosea
   gerryi Thony, 1996, syn. n. of Tambana funebris (Berio, 1973), comb. n.
   (Trichosea). The updated checklist of 26 taxa of Tambana is presented.
   Short diagnoses are given for the described species. In addition the
   related genus Xanthomantis Warren, 1909 with two species X. cornelia
   (Staudinger, 1888) and X. contaminata (Draudt, 1937) is reviewed.

DT Article
TI Revision of the Nearctic species of the genus Iphthiminus Spilman
   (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae).
AU Gardiner, Rebekka M.
   Pollock, Darren A.
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 3
PS 352-391
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Nearctic species of Iphthiminus Spilman (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae) are
   revised by examining external morphological structures and genital
   characters. Of the six Nearctic species, only three are considered
   valid: Iphthiminus serratus (Mannerheim 1843), I. opacus (Leconte 1866),
   and I. lewisii (Horn 1870). Photographs are taken to highlight
   structures and a key is created to identify the species. Three names are
   synonymized: (senior synonym in brackets) I. sublaevis (Bland 1865)
   (=Nyctobates sublaevis (Bland 1865)), I. salebrosus (Casey 1924)
   (=Iphthimus salebrosus (Casey 1924)) are synonymized under I. serratus
   (Mannerheim 1843) (=Nyctobates serratus (Mannerheim 1843)), and I.
   laevissimus (Casey 1890 (=Iphthimus laevissimus (Casey 1890)) is
   synonymized under Iphthiminus lewisii (Horn 1870) (=Iphthimus lewisii
   (Horn 1870)). Lectotypes are designated for Iphthimus serratus lewisii
   Horn 1870 and Iphthimus opacus LeConte 1866.

   laevissimus Casey 1890, p. 364].

DT Article
TI Review of the Gauromydas giant flies (Insecta, Diptera, Mydidae), with
   descriptions of two new species from Central and South America.
AU Calhau, Julia (juliacalhau@gmail.com) 
   Lamas, Carlos Jose Einicker
   Nihei, Silvio Shigueo
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 3
PS 392-411
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Gauromydas Wilcox, Papavero & Pimentel, 1989 are giant flies, and
   include the largest fly known, G. heros (Perty, 1833). This genus was
   originally erected to group four Neotropical species, namely G. apicalis
   (Wiedemann, 1830), G. autuorii (d'Andretta, 1951), G. heros, and G.
   mystaceus (Wiedemann, 1830). As with most of the remaining Mydidae,
   adults of Gauromydas are very rarely collected. We here describe two new
   species of Gauromydas (G. mateus sp. nov. and G. papaveroi sp. nov.)
   discovered in entomological collections, including specimens unstudied
   for up to eight decades. We also provide revised diagnoses for the
   remaining four species of Gauromydas, along with a new key and new
   distribution records for the genus.
C1 Calhau, Julia; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Sao Paulo, SP, BR-04263000
   BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM juliacalhau@gmail.com

   Silvio/D-3615-2012
OI Calhau, Julia/0000-0003-0484-9442; Lamas, Carlos Jose
   E/0000-0002-7750-590X;

   [Brazil /  / ].

DT Article
TI New species of Histiotus (Chiroptera: Vespertilionidae) from
   northeastern Brazil.
AU Feijo, Anderson (andekson@gmail.com) 
   Da Rocha, Patricio Adriano
   Althoff, Sergio Luiz
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 3
PS 412-427
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 2
U2 10
AB Histiotus are vespertilionid bats endemic to South America, easily
   recognized by its very long ears. During a twelvemonth bat inventory in
   northeastern Brazil, eleven specimens of Histiotus were collected with a
   unique combination of characters that did not match those of any known
   species. In this paper, we describe these specimens as a new species.
   Histiotus sp. nov is distinguished from its congeners by its pale
   transparent wings and translucent ears, a triangular-shaped ear with a
   prominent lobe in the inner border connected by a band ([approximately]4
   mm) across the forehead; its general golden-brownish body color and
   well-marked bicolor dorsal hairs. Its geographic distribution is unique
   among vespertilionids, arranged in a northeast-southwest diagonal across
   South America, includes the Caatinga and Cerrado of Brazil and Chaco of
   Bolivia. The available data suggest a seasonal reproductive pattern,
   with births occurring in the mid to late rainy season.
C1 Feijo, Anderson; Univ Fed Paraiba, CCEN, Campus 1, Joao Pessoa, Paraiba,
   BR-58051900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM andekson@gmail.com
RI Rocha, Patricio/B-3875-2013; Althoff, Sergio Luiz/AAE-5820-2020; Feijo,
   Anderson/F-4287-2018
OI Rocha, Patricio/0000-0003-1661-3779; Althoff, Sergio
   Luiz/0000-0002-0877-5156
SC Zoology
SN 1175-5326; 1175-5334
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Neotropical region;
   South America
DE Histiotus diaphanopterus [Bolivia /  / New species] [Brazil /  / ].

TI Nossidium katyae, a new species of Bolivian Ptiliidae (Coleoptera),
   described and figured.
AU Darby, Michael (m.darby@nhm.ac.uk) 
SO Zootaxa
VL 4048
IS 3
PS 436-440
PD Nov 26 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB This is the third report on a collection of Ptiliidae from Bolivian
   forest leaf litter made by Dr Petr Banar of the Brno Museum (Czech
   Republic) in 2013. A new species Nossidium katyae, is described and
   figured on the basis of a single specimen collected in the Amboro
   National Park. Comparative figures of Nossidium pilosellum Marsham are
   provided together with a brief synopsis of views on the desirability of
   establishing a new subfamily within the Ptiliidae to include Nossidium
   group species.

PT J
AN ZOOR15205032531
DT Article
TI Review of the Japanese Species of the Genus Cicindela (Sophiodela)
   (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Cicindelinae) Based on the Characters of
   Internal Sac.
AU Fukuda, Yuki (yuki03go3@gmail.com) 
   Yamasako, Junsuke
   Ogawa, Ryo
   Sakai, Masahiro
SO Elytra
VL 5
IS 2
PS 269-280
PD Nov 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Japanese species of Cicindela (Sophiodela) are reviewed and
   redefined on the basis of the characteristics of the inflated internal
   sac. Cicindela (S.) japonica and C. (S.) okinawana are treated as an
   independent species from a subspecies of C. (S.) chinensis because of
   the differentiated characteristics of the internal sac. Cicindela (S.)
   ferriei indigonacea is synonymized with C. (S.) ferriei ferriei, because
   there is no significant difference in the structure of internal sac
   between the subspecies. As a result, the Japanese Sophiodela comprises
   C. (S.) ferriei FLEUTIAUX, 1895, C. (S.) japonica THUNBERG, 1781, and C.
   (S.) okinawana NAKANE, 1957. They essentially share the basic features
   of the internal sac and form a related species group. In addition, the
   subgenus is relatively more similar to the genus Cosmodela than
   Cicindela (Cicindela), and therefore it seems to have a closer
   relationship with Cosmodela.
C1 Fukuda, Yuki; Fiore Yonehara 203,Yonehara 4-6-26, Yonago, Tottori,
   6830804, Japan, Japan.
EM yuki03go3@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0387-5733
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Status; Key; General
   morphology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cicindela (Sophiodela) [General morphology / Internal sac characters /
   Taxonomic review] [Japan /  / Key to species] [ /  / ]. 
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) okinawana [Japan / Ryukyu Islands, Yonaguni-jima
   Island / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Cicindela (Sophiodela) - Nakane 1955 (Carabidae): [Key to species,
   Japan, Modified key, p. 276]. 
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) chinensis japonica - Thunberg 1781 (Carabidae):
   [Raised to, Cicindela (Sophiodela) japonica, p. 271]. 
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) chinensis okinawana - Nakane 1957 (Carabidae):
   [Raised to, Cicindela (Sophiodela) okinawana, p. 273]. 
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) ferriei ferriei - Fleutiaux 1895 (Carabidae):
   [Syn nov, Cicindela (Sophiodela) ferriei indigonacea Miwa 1935, p. 275].
   
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) japonica - Thunberg 1781 (Carabidae): [Raised
   from, Cicindela (Sophiodela) chinensis japonica, p. 271]. 
   Cicindela (Sophiodela) okinawana - Nakane 1957 (Carabidae): [Raised
   from, Cicindela (Sophiodela) chinensis okinawana, p. 273; New record].

TI A New Hikosanoagonum (Coleoptera, Carabidae) from West Japan.
AU Morita, Seiji
   Ito, Yoshiyuki
SO Elytra
VL 5
IS 2
PS 293-297
PD Nov 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new platynine carabid species, Hikosanoagonum bungo MORITA et Y. ITO,
   sp. nov. is described from Shikoku and Kyusyu, West Japan. It is similar
   in general appearance to H. latior S. UENO from Amami-Oshima Is.,
   southwestern Japan, but differs from that species mainly in the shape of
   pronotum and elytral basal parts, and the impunctate elytral striae.

DT Article
TI Four New Species of the Genus Stenus LATREILLE (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae, Steninae) of Japan, with Discovery of the Female of S.
   miroku from Mt. Sanbe, Shimane Prefecture.
AU Naomi, Shun-Ichiro (naostenus@hb.tp1.jp) 
   Nomura, Shuhei
   Kamezawa, Hiromu
SO Elytra
VL 5
IS 2
PS 319-330
PD Nov 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This is the 55th taxonomic study on the subfamily Steninae (Coleoptera,
   Staphylinidae) from Japan, with descriptions of four new species of the
   genus Stenus LATREILLE. The new species of Stenus described herein are
   as follows: S. tsukubamontis (Ibaraki Pref.), S. nogohakusanus (Ishikawa
   Pref.), S. volkerputhzi (Ishikawa Pref.) and S. deltoides (Ishikawa and
   Fukui Prefs.). The taxonomically important characters including several
   posterior abdominal segments, aedeagus, endophallic structures and
   spermatheca are illustrated in detail. The female of S. miroku NAOMI,
   2006 is first discovered from Mt. Sanbe, Shimane Pref.; and the
   spermatheca and gonocoxites are first described and illustrated.
C1 Naomi, Shun-Ichiro; Nat Hist Museum & Inst, Chuo Ku, 955-2 Aoba Cho,
   Chiba, Chiba, 2608682, Japan, Japan.
EM naostenus@hb.tp1.jp
SC Zoology
SN 0387-5733
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Stenus deltoides; Stenus nogohakusanus; Stenus tsukubamontis; Stenus
   volkerputhzi [Japan /  / New species]. 
   Stenus miroku [Japan / Honshu, Shimane, Mt. Sanbe / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Stenus deltoides (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 326]. 
   Stenus miroku - Naomi 2006 (Staphylinidae): [First time described,
   Female, p. 329; First time figured, Spermatheca & gonocoxites, p. 328;
   New record]. 
   Stenus nogohakusanus (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 322]. 
   Stenus tsukubamontis (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 320]. 
   Stenus volkerputhzi (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Japan, P. 324].

TI New or Little-known Tenebrionid Species (Coleoptera) from Japan (16)
   Descriptions of Eight New Species of Genera Allecula and Borboresthes
   (Alleculinae, Alleculini), and Redescription of the Known Species with
   Proposal for Two New Synonyms.
AU Akita, Katsumi
   Masumoto, Kimio
SO Elytra
VL 5
IS 2
PS 357-377
PD Nov 25 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Five new species of the genus Allecula FABRICIUS, 1801 and three new
   species of the genus Borboresthes FAIRMAIRE, 1897 are described from
   Japan: Allecula (Allecula) yakushimana AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; A.
   (A.) okinawana AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; A. (A.) toyoshimai AKITA et
   MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; A. (A.) ryukyuensis AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; A.
   (A.) tatsunosukei AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; Borboresthes arimotoi
   AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; B. satoi AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov.; B.
   aokii AKITA et MASUMOTO, sp. nov. Allecula (Allecula) nipponica
   MIYATAKE, 1985 is redescribed, and A. (A.) ontakensis MAEDA et NAKANE,
   1988 is regarded as a junior synonym of A. (A.) nipponica. After
   examining syntypes of A. (A.) noctivaga LEWIS, 1895, the lectotype is
   designated. Furthermore, A. (A.) alcitai HANATSUKA, MASUMOTO et KON,
   2006 is regarded as a junior synonym of A. (A.) noctivaga.

   388; Comb nov, Transferred from Ischnodactylus, p. 386].
